used_raw_datum_texts: Dec 7, 1941: Mobilization Lifts EconomyThe Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor draws United States into World War II. Mobilization for war finally lifts the American economy permanently out of the Great Depression.Back

event.name: Herbert Hoover assumes office as President of the United States
event.description: Herbert Hoover assumes office as the 31st President of the United States, but his laissez-faire approach to economics did not help relieve the Great Depression, leading to a bad reputation.

event.name: 25 years before stock market reaches pre-Wall Street Crash high
event.description: After this date, it would be 25 years before the stock market would reach its pre-Wall Street Crash high, indicating the long-lasting impact of the crash.

event.name: Black Thursday stock market crash
event.description: Black Thursday prompts the start of the stock market crash, plunging the country and the rest of the world into the Great Depression. The price of stocks dropped by 11%, leading to a significant economic downturn.

event.name: Black Monday stock market crash
event.description: Stock prices fell by 13% on Black Monday, exacerbating the impact of the stock market crash and further contributing to the onset of the Great Depression.

event.name: Black Tuesday
event.description: On October 29, 1929, the stock market crashed, leading to a 12% loss and the trading of 16 million shares. The panic was exacerbated by the intervention of banks.

event.name: Sideways Trading Begins
event.description: On November 23, 1929, the stock market began sideways trading after plummeting to the bottom. President Hoover's statement about the economic future added to the unawareness of the trouble coming.

event.name: Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act Signed
event.description: On June 17, 1930, President Hoover signed the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act, raising taxes on 900 different imports. The aim was to support farmers, but it ended up impacting international trade and causing problems in Europe. This led to a decrease in international trade and economic struggles.

event.name: Bank of Tennessee Failure
event.description: The Bank of Tennessee fails, causing failures in associated banks and contributing to weaknesses in the banking system. This had a significant impact on the economy, leading to a series of bank failures and economic downturn.

event.name: Bank of the United States Failure
event.description: On December 11, 1931, the Bank of the United States failed, causing the biggest bank failure in the history of the United States. This event had a significant impact on the economic crisis during the Great Depression.

event.name: President Roosevelt is Elected
event.description: Democratic candidate Franklin D. Roosevelt is elected President of the United States after defeating Herbert Hoover in a landslide victory. Roosevelt got 22,800,000 popular votes, compared to Hoover who got 15,750,000. Unemployment Rate: 23.6%.

event.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt's 'New Deal' Speech
event.description: Franklin D. Roosevelt, a 1932 presidential candidate, gives his “New Deal” speech to the public to reveal his plans for economic recovery.

event.name: Revenue Act of 1932
event.description: President Hoover signs the Revenue Act of 1932, which increases the top income tax rate to 63%. Believing it would restore confidence and reduce the federal deficit, the taxes being pushed to a higher rate would actually make the depression worse.

event.name: President Roosevelt's First Hundred Days
event.description: President Roosevelt begins his 'first hundred days' in office, introducing 15 laws rapidly to begin tackling the Great Depression.

event.name: Bank Holiday
event.description: President Roosevelt closes all banks for a 'bank holiday' to address the economic crisis during the Great Depression.

event.name: Emergency Banking Act
event.description: President Roosevelt creates the Emergency Banking Act, closing all banks in the United States to prevent further economic failures and launching the New Deal.

event.name: Fireside Chats Begin
event.description: President Roosevelt begins his 'Fireside Chats,' a series of broadcasts from his home to keep the country updated on the government’s attempts to combat the Great Depression.

event.name: Government Economy Act
event.description: The Government Economy Act is introduced in an attempt to reduce government spending to support the New Deal during the Great Depression.

event.name: Beer-Wine Revenue Act
event.description: The Beer-Wine Revenue Act is introduced, raising revenue by placing taxes on alcohol sales and bringing an end to the Prohibition era.

event.name: Dr. Francis Townsend proposes Pension Plan
event.description: Dr. Francis Townsend proposes a state-funded pension plan for the elderly in a letter to the Long Beach Press-Telegram, suggesting it as a way to boost employment and consumption.

event.name: Creation of 4 million construction jobs by Civil Works Administration
event.description: The Civil Works Administration creates 4 million construction jobs, providing employment during the Great Depression. Meanwhile, dust storms hit Oklahoma and surrounding states, leading to a compromising position for farmers.

event.name: Incorporation of Old Age Revolving Pensions Ltd. by Dr. Francis Townsend
event.description: Dr. Francis Townsend officially incorporates the Old Age Revolving Pensions Ltd., furthering his efforts to address the economic challenges faced by the elderly during the Great Depression.

event.name: Introduction of Gold Reserve Act
event.description: The Gold Reserve Act is introduced, doubling the price of gold and banning private ownership, impacting the economic and financial landscape during the Great Depression.

event.name: Foundation of Share Our Wealth society by Huey Long
event.description: Huey Long founds the Share Our Wealth society, aiming to redistribute the 'excess fortunes' of the rich to the poor, addressing economic inequality during the Great Depression.

event.name: Black Sunday Dust Storm
event.description: On April 15, 1934, the worst dust storm in U.S. history, known as Black Sunday, devastated the Great Plains, causing severe ecological and agricultural damage.

event.name: Soil Conservation Act
event.description: On April 15, 1934, President Roosevelt introduced the Soil Conservation Act to help farmers learn sustainable agricultural practices, aiming to combat the ecological devastation caused by events like the Black Sunday dust storm.

event.name: Federal Housing Administration and Securities and Exchange Commission
event.description: On June 27, 1934, the Federal Housing Administration provided mortgage insurance, and the Securities and Exchange Commission was established to regulate the stock market, aiming to stabilize the economy and prevent future financial crises.

event.name: Townsend Plan and Share Our Wealth Society
event.description: In 1935, support for the Townsend Plan and the Share Our Wealth Society grew significantly, with millions of Americans advocating for economic reforms to address the challenges of the Great Depression.

event.name: Resettlement Administration
event.description: On April 30, 1935, the Resettlement Administration provided training and loans to farmers, aiming to address the challenges of agricultural and rural communities during the Great Depression.

event.name: Works Progress Administration
event.description: On May 6, 1935, the Works Progress Administration was created, hiring millions of people to address the unemployment crisis, and undertaking various public works projects to stimulate the economy during the Great Depression.

event.name: Rural Electrification Act Implemented
event.description: The Rural Electrification Act is implemented to help farms generate electricity, bringing electricity to rural areas and improving the lives of farmers.

event.name: President Roosevelt Re-elected to Second Presidential Term
event.description: President Roosevelt is re-elected to a second presidential term, continuing his efforts to address the challenges of the Great Depression and its associated impacts.

event.name: Publication of The Grapes of Wrath
event.description: On April 14, 1939, John Steinbeck publishes his novel The Grapes of Wrath, depicting the hardships of the 1930s through a migrating family from Oklahoma.

event.name: Roaring Twenties Economic Boom
event.description: The period from January to June 1929 saw a significant economic boom known as the Roaring Twenties, with record profits, retail sales, construction starts, and stock market gains. However, the surplus of wheat from 1928 led to a strain on commodity markets and farmers' incomes.

event.name: Mini-Stock Market Crash
event.description: A mini-stock market crash occurred after the Federal Reserve warned of excessive speculation. The crash was averted two days later when National City Bank injected $25 million in credit into the stock market.

event.name: Agricultural Marketing Act of 1929
event.description: The Agricultural Marketing Act of 1929 was signed into law, providing emergency loans of around $100 million to struggling farmers.

event.name: Dow Jones Industrial Average Peaks
event.description: The Dow Jones Industrial Average peaks at 381.17, a level it would not reach again until November 23, 1954.

event.name: Wall Street Crash of 1929 Begins
event.description: The infamous Wall Street Crash of 1929 begins, leading to a significant drop in stock values and the start of the Great Depression.

event.name: Black Tuesday
event.description: On 'Black Tuesday', the New York Stock Exchange collapses, with the Dow Jones closing down over 12%, marking one of the most devastating events of the Great Depression.

event.name: Stock Market Bottoms Out
event.description: The stock market bottoms out at 198.60, followed by a bear market that would last until April 1930, contributing to the severity of the Great Depression.

event.name: Dow Reaches Secondary Closing Peak
event.description: The Dow reaches a secondary closing peak of 294.07, followed by a long stagnation until a severe decline began in April 1931, reflecting the ongoing economic challenges of the Great Depression.

event.name: Automobile Sales Decline
event.description: Automobile sales fall below 1928 levels, indicating the continued economic downturn and impact of the Great Depression on consumer spending.

event.name: Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act passed
event.description: The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act was passed, placing more stress on the weakening global economy, primarily through the collapse in trade of agricultural products, which strained banks that had lent heavily to farmers. It further decreased trade of manufactured products, leading to layoffs and reduced corporate profits, weakening the economy.

event.name: 1930 German federal election
event.description: The 1930 German federal election was held, with strong gains for the Nazis and the Communists, who became the second-largest party in the Reichstag. The parties constituting the incumbent pro-democratic Weimar Coalition suffered catastrophic losses.

event.name: Creditanstalt becomes insolvent
event.description: Creditanstalt, Austria's premier bank with major stakes across a variety of industries, becomes insolvent after being forced to assume liabilities from three other insolvent banks, triggering a cascading effect of bank failures across Central Europe. The collapse of Creditanstalt caused the Bank of France, the National Bank of Belgium, the Netherlands Bank, and the Swiss National Bank to begin a run on the U.S. dollar for their gold reserves, and forced the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates from 1.5% to 3.5% to maintain the gold standards, which in turn contributed to the deepening of the Depression and the second round of banking failures in the U.S. during the summer of 1931.

event.name: Britain leaves the gold standard
event.description: On September 21, 1931, Britain left the gold standard, leading to a 25% depreciation of the pound sterling. Despite warnings of disaster, the departure proved beneficial to the British economy, as exports became more competitive. This event also allowed the Bank of England to engage in money creation and reduce interest rates, leading to economic growth and reduced unemployment.

event.name: United Kingdom General election, 1931
event.description: On October 27, 1931, the United Kingdom General election took place, destroying the Labour Party and delivering a landslide victory to the Conservative Party.

event.name: Creation of Reconstruction Finance Corporation
event.description: The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is created to lend $2 billion to troubled financial institutions that were not part of the Federal Reserve System that were solvent in the long-run. By 1941, the RFC would lend out some $9.5 billion to banks, railroads, and mortgage associations, as well as state and local governments.

event.name: Passing of the Revenue Act of 1932
event.description: The Revenue Act of 1932 is signed into law, raising taxes on personal income, corporate income, and sales taxes on various goods.

event.name: Dow Jones Industrial Index bottoms out
event.description: The Dow Jones Industrial Index bottoms out at 41.22, the lowest level recorded in the 20th century and representing an 89% loss from its peak in September 1929.

event.name: German federal election, July 1932
event.description: The Nazi Party, led by Adolf Hitler, becomes the largest party in the Reichstag (but lacks a majority). For the first time, the combined strength of the Communists and Nazis means that there is an anti-democratic majority in Germany.

event.name: German federal election, November 1932
event.description: The last free and fair all-German election until 1990 is held. A minor setback for the Nazi Party, a campaign of mass violence and intimidation would begin in the run up to the next election in March 1933. Nonetheless, the anti-democratic majority between the Communists and Nazis is narrowly maintained.

event.name: 1932 United States elections
event.description: Franklin D. Roosevelt is elected 32nd President of the United States in a landslide, the Democratic Party wins massive majorities in both chambers of Congress.

event.name: Michigan Declares Indefinite Bank Holiday
event.description: Michigan becomes the first state in the U.S. to declare an indefinite bank holiday, in an attempt to stem the impending collapse of First National Bank of Detroit and the Guardian National Bank of Commerce, the two largest banks in Detroit. This action was taken due to the threat of failure if the Ford Motor Company withdrew all of its deposits in the two banks, leading to widespread unemployment and economic instability.

event.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt's Inauguration
event.description: Franklin D. Roosevelt is inaugurated as the 32nd President of the United States, marking the beginning of his presidency during the Great Depression.

event.name: German Federal Election, March 1933
event.description: The Nazi Party wins a narrow majority of seats in the German federal election, marking a significant step towards their consolidation of power in Germany.

event.name: Executive Order 2009 Suspends Banking Activity
event.description: Executive Order 2009 suspends all banking activity for one week in response to renewed stress on major New York City banks, aiming to prevent further deepening of the Depression.

event.name: Enactment of the Emergency Banking Act
event.description: The Emergency Banking Act is enacted, enabling the restructuring of the banking system and the creation of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) to restore confidence in the banking system during the Great Depression.

event.name: Signing of the Economy Act of 1933
event.description: The controversial Economy Act of 1933 is signed into law, aiming to reduce government outlays and balance the budget during the economic crisis of the Great Depression.

event.name: Creation of the Civilian Conservation Corps
event.description: The Civilian Conservation Corps, a public works relief program, is created as part of the New Deal programs to provide employment and conservation efforts during the Great Depression.

event.name: Executive Order 6102 Forbids Hoarding of Gold
event.description: President Franklin D. Roosevelt issues Executive Order 6102, forbidding the hoarding of gold coin, bullion, and certificates, as a measure to stabilize the economy during the Great Depression.

event.name: Enactment of the Agricultural Adjustment Act
event.description: The Agricultural Adjustment Act is enacted, aiming to boost agricultural prices by reducing surpluses during the Great Depression.

event.name: Enactment of the Securities Act of 1933
event.description: The Securities Act of 1933 is enacted, requiring the registration of all sales and purchases of financial securities, aiming to combat insider trading and reduce transaction risk during the Great Depression.

event.name: Creation of the Civil Works Administration
event.description: The Civil Works Administration is created, employing over 4 million people and distributing funds for work programs during the Great Depression.

event.name: Repeal of Prohibition at the National Level
event.description: Prohibition is repealed at the national level, marking the end of the era of alcohol prohibition in the United States and its impact on organized crime, employment, and state tax revenues.

event.name: Stock Market Crash of 1929
event.description: The stock market crash of 1929, also known as Black Thursday, kicked off with stock prices immediately falling 11%. Although Wall Street bankers bought stocks, only 2% was lost by the time the market closed. The following days saw further fluctuations in stock prices.

event.name: Herbert Hoover Became President
event.description: Herbert Hoover became president on March 4, 1929. His laissez-faire economic policies did little to stop the Great Depression. He believed in a free-market economy and lowered the top income tax rate from 25% to 24%.

event.name: Dow Reached Closing Record of 381.7
event.description: On September 3, 1929, the Dow reached a closing record of 381.7. The stock market would not return to its pre-crash high for the next 25 years.

event.name: Black Monday
event.description: On October 28, 1929, stocks prices fell 13%, marking the infamous Black Monday during the stock market crash of 1929.

event.name: Black Tuesday Market Crash
event.description: On Black Tuesday, the market lost another 12% as a record 16 million shares were traded. Banks intervention worsened the panic, leading to a significant economic downturn.

event.name: Stock Market Bottom
event.description: The stock market hit bottom and began trading sideways, marking a critical point in the economic downturn of the Great Depression.

event.name: Soup Kitchen
event.description: Dolly Gann, sister of U.S. vice president Charles Curtis, helps serve meals to the hungry at a Salvation Army soup kitchen on December 27, 1930, reflecting the widespread impact of the Great Depression on the American society.

event.name: Signing of the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act
event.description: In 1930, President Hoover signed the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act, which raised taxes on 900 imports. Initially intended to assist farmers, it resulted in imposing tariffs on numerous other products, leading to a trade war and the collapse of international trade.

event.name: Creation of the Department of Veterans Affairs
event.description: On July 21, 1930, President Hoover created the Department of Veterans Affairs, aiming to provide support and services to American veterans. This was a significant step in addressing the needs of veterans following World War I.

event.name: Bank of Tennessee Failure
event.description: The failure of the Bank of Tennessee on November 7, 1930, led to the collapse of affiliate banks in the following days, contributing to the worsening of the economy. The weaknesses in the banking system, with only one-third of the nation's banks being part of the Federal Reserve system, exacerbated the situation, leading to bank runs and widespread failures.

event.name: Bank of the United States Failure
event.description: On December 11, 1930, the failure of the Bank of the United States, the fourth-largest bank in the nation at the time, marked the largest bank failure in history. This event further deepened the economic crisis, leading to significant budget deficits, an 8.5% contraction in the economy, and a rise in unemployment to 8.7%.

event.name: Revenue Act of 1932
event.description: On June 6, 1932, President Hoover signed the Revenue Act of 1932, increasing the top income tax rate to 63% in an attempt to reduce the federal deficit, but it had a negative impact on the economy during the Great Depression.

event.name: Dow Jones Industrial Average hits bottom at 41.22
event.description: On July 8, 1932, the Dow Jones Industrial Average hit a low of 41.22, marking a 90% decline from its pre-crash high in September 1929. This event symbolized the depth of the Great Depression's impact on the stock market.

event.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt launches the New Deal with the Emergency Banking Act
event.description: On March 9, 1933, President Franklin D. Roosevelt initiated the New Deal with the Emergency Banking Act, which aimed to stabilize the banking system by temporarily closing all U.S. banks to prevent further failures during the Great Depression.

event.name: Government Economy Act reduces government spending for New Deal financing
event.description: The Government Economy Act, enacted on March 20, 1933, aimed to reduce government spending to finance the New Deal initiatives, reflecting the government's efforts to address the economic challenges of the Great Depression.

event.name: Beer-Wine Revenue Act ends Prohibition and introduces alcohol sales tax
event.description: On March 22, 1933, the Beer-Wine Revenue Act was passed, ending Prohibition and introducing taxes on alcohol sales to generate revenue for the government during the Great Depression.

event.name: Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) established to employ workers for public land maintenance
event.description: The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) was launched on March 31, 1933, as part of the New Deal to address unemployment by hiring 3 million workers for the maintenance of public lands, reflecting the government's efforts to stimulate the economy during the Great Depression.

event.name: FDR Abandoned Gold Standard
event.description: On April 19, 1933, FDR stopped a run on gold by abandoning the gold standard and ordered the exchange of private gold for dollars.

event.name: Agricultural Adjustment Act
event.description: On May 11, 1933, the Agricultural Adjustment Act was enacted to pay farmers to limit crops, thus raising prices, as a measure to combat the agricultural crisis during the Great Depression.

event.name: Emergency Farm Mortgage Act
event.description: The Emergency Farm Mortgage Act of May 12, 1933, provided loans to save farms from foreclosure during the Great Depression.

event.name: Tennessee Valley Authority Act
event.description: On May 12, 1933, the Tennessee Valley Authority Act was passed to build power stations in the poorest area in the nation during the Great Depression.

event.name: National Recovery Administration
event.description: On June 14, 1933, the National Recovery Administration was established to outlaw child labor, establish a minimum wage, limit the workday to eight hours, and allow trade unions to bargain with employers during the Great Depression.

event.name: Emergency Railroad Transportation Act
event.description: On June 15, 1933, the Emergency Railroad Transportation Act was enacted to coordinate the national railway systems during the Great Depression.

event.name: Creation of Civil Works Administration
event.description: The Civil Works Administration was created, providing 4 million construction jobs to combat unemployment during the Great Depression. This initiative aimed to stimulate the economy and address the widespread unemployment crisis.

event.name: Gold Reserve Act
event.description: The Gold Reserve Act was passed, prohibiting private ownership of gold and doubling its price, marking a significant shift in the regulation and value of gold during the Great Depression.

event.name: Black Sunday Dust Storm
event.description: Black Sunday, the worst dust storm ever recorded, occurred during the Great Depression, prompting FDR to pass the Soil Conservation Act to address the environmental devastation and promote sustainable farming methods.

event.name: Federal Housing Administration provided federal mortgage insurance
event.description: The Federal Housing Administration provided federal mortgage insurance to help revive the housing market and provide affordable housing for Americans. This was a key component of the New Deal programs aimed at stimulating the economy and addressing the housing crisis during the Great Depression.

event.name: Securities and Exchange Commission regulated the stock market
event.description: The Securities and Exchange Commission was established to regulate the stock market and protect investors from fraudulent activities. This was a crucial step in restoring confidence in the financial system after the stock market crash of 1929.

event.name: FCC consolidated all federal regulation of telephone, telegraph, and radio communications
event.description: The FCC's consolidation of federal regulation of communication technologies aimed to streamline oversight and ensure fair and efficient communication services for the public. This was a significant development in the modernization of communication infrastructure in the United States.

event.name: Soil Conservation & Domestic Allotment Act paid farmers to plant soil-building crops
event.description: The Soil Conservation & Domestic Allotment Act aimed to address soil erosion and promote sustainable farming practices by providing financial incentives for farmers to plant soil-building crops. This initiative was crucial for revitalizing the agricultural sector during the Great Depression.

event.name: Emergency Relief Appropriation created the Works Progress Administration
event.description: The Emergency Relief Appropriation led to the establishment of the Works Progress Administration, which employed millions of people in various public works projects, providing much-needed jobs and infrastructure improvements during the Great Depression.

event.name: Rural Electrification Act
event.description: The Rural Electrification Act was passed on May 20, 1935, and it aimed to provide electricity to rural areas, particularly farms, which greatly improved their productivity and quality of life.

event.name: National Labor Relations Act/Wagner Act
event.description: The National Labor Relations Act, also known as the Wagner Act, was enacted on July 22, 1935, to protect workers' rights and establish the National Labor Relations Board, ensuring fair labor practices and collective bargaining.

event.name: Resettlement Administration
event.description: The Resettlement Administration, established on April 30, 1935, provided training and loans to farmers, aiming to improve their living conditions and agricultural practices during the Great Depression.

event.name: Resumption of the Depression
event.description: On May 26, 1937, the economy started contracting again, marking the resumption of the Great Depression.

event.name: Japan attacked Pearl Harbor
event.description: On December 7, 1941, Japan launched a surprise military strike on the United States naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, leading to the United States' entry into World War II.

event.name: The Dow closed at 382.74
event.description: On November 23, 1954, the Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 382.74, surpassing the previous record set on September 3, 1929, reflecting the post-World War II economic growth and recovery.

event.name: The Smoot-Hawley Tariff
event.description: The Smoot-Hawley Tariff raised duties on agricultural and manufactured goods, leading to foreign retaliation and exacerbating the Great Depression.

event.name: National Anthem Act
event.description: President Herbert Hoover signs an act making the 'Star-Spangled Banner' the national anthem of the United States.

event.name: Scottsboro Boys Case
event.description: Nine black youths, known as the 'Scottsboro Boys', are charged with rape, leading to a landmark case that established the right of African Americans to serve on juries.

event.name: Reconstruction Finance Corporation Establishment
event.description: The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is established to provide loans to banks, railroads, and insurance companies, aiming to stabilize the economy during the Great Depression.

event.name: Lindbergh Kidnapping
event.description: The son of aviator Charles Lindbergh is kidnapped, leading to a high-profile and tragic criminal case.

event.name: Franklin Roosevelt's 'New Deal' Promise
event.description: Democratic presidential candidate Franklin Roosevelt promises a 'New Deal' for the American people, marking a pivotal moment in U.S. history and the Great Depression era.

event.name: Bonus Army removed from Washington
event.description: President Herbert Hoover orders the army to remove 15,000 WWI veterans who had been camped in Washington for two months demanding early payment of a bonus due in 1945. The veterans were forcibly evicted from their camp, leading to a violent clash with the authorities.

event.name: Adolf Hitler appointed Chancellor of Germany
event.description: Adolf Hitler, leader of Germany's Nazi party, is appointed Chancellor, marking a significant turning point in German politics and paving the way for the establishment of a totalitarian regime.

event.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt becomes President and launches the New Deal
event.description: Franklin D. Roosevelt becomes President and launches the New Deal, a series of programs and reforms aimed at addressing the economic challenges of the Great Depression. In his inaugural address, he delivers the iconic line: 'The only thing we have to fear is fear itself.'

event.name: Repeal of Prohibition
event.description: Prohibition, which banned the production, importation, and sale of alcoholic beverages, is repealed, ending a 13-year period of prohibition in the United States. This event marked a significant shift in social and legal policies.

event.name: Dr. Francis Townsend proposes federally-funded pensions for the elderly
event.description: Dr. Francis Townsend, a retired dentist, advocates for the establishment of federally-funded pensions to support the elderly population, aiming to address the economic challenges faced by senior citizens during the Great Depression.

event.name: John Dillinger is shot and killed by the FBI
event.description: John Dillinger, notorious bank robber and Public Enemy Number 1, is fatally shot by the FBI as he exits a movie theater in Chicago, marking a significant event in the pursuit of justice against organized crime during the Great Depression era.

event.name: The Nuremberg Laws strip German Jews of citizenship and prohibit intermarriage with non-Jews
event.description: The Nuremberg Laws, enacted by the Nazi regime, deprive German Jews of their citizenship and impose severe restrictions on their rights, leading to widespread discrimination and persecution within the society.

event.name: The Supreme Court declares the national industrial Recovery Act unconstitutional
event.description: The Supreme Court's ruling declares the national industrial Recovery Act unconstitutional, signaling a shift in the balance of power between federal legislation and economic regulations, impacting the government's intervention in labor and business practices during the Great Depression.

event.name: Alcoholic Anonymous is organized in New York City
event.description: Alcoholic Anonymous, a support group for individuals struggling with alcohol addiction, is founded in New York City, providing a platform for mutual aid and sobriety maintenance during a time of social and economic turmoil.

event.name: The Wagner Act guarantees workers' right to bargain collectively
event.description: The Wagner Act, also known as the National Labor Relations Act, secures the rights of workers to engage in collective bargaining and protects their freedom to organize labor unions, marking a pivotal development in labor rights and industrial relations during the Great Depression.

event.name: President Roosevelt signs the Social Security Act
event.description: President Roosevelt signs the Social Security Act into law, establishing a system of social insurance to provide economic security for the elderly, unemployed, and disadvantaged individuals, representing a landmark initiative in the development of social welfare programs during the Great Depression.

event.name: Huey Long is assassinated in Louisiana's state capitol
event.description: Huey Long, a prominent political figure and advocate for wealth redistribution, is assassinated in Louisiana's state capitol, marking the tragic end of his influential populist movement during the Great Depression era.

event.name: Formation of the Committee for Industrial Organization
event.description: The Committee for Industrial Organization was formed with John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, as its head. It later became the Congress of Industrial Organizations in 1938, and unlike the AFL, it did not limit membership to skilled workers.

event.name: German Troops Occupy the Rhineland
event.description: In violation of the Versailles Treaty ending WWI, 4,000 German troops occupy the Rhineland, escalating tensions in Europe.

event.name: Civil War Erupts in Spain
event.description: Civil War erupts in Spain, ending the country's five-year experiment with democracy. Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini provide arms to Gen. Francisco Franco, who defeats the Loyalists in 1939 and imposes a dictatorship.

event.name: President Roosevelt proposes "court packing" scheme
event.description: President Roosevelt proposes a plan to expand the Supreme Court by adding more justices, which is seen as an attempt to secure favorable rulings for his New Deal policies.

event.name: General Motors recognizes the United Automobile Workers after a 44-day occupation
event.description: General Motors acknowledges the United Automobile Workers union after a prolonged occupation of its factories, marking a significant victory for labor rights and collective bargaining.

event.name: School fire in New London, Texas kills 294
event.description: A devastating school fire in New London, Texas claims the lives of 294 individuals, mostly children, leading to improved safety regulations and awareness in educational institutions.

event.name: Supreme Court upholds minimum wage law for women
event.description: The Supreme Court's decision to uphold a minimum wage law for women sets a precedent for gender equality in labor rights and contributes to the advancement of fair working conditions.

event.name: Supreme Court upholds National Labor Relations Act of 1935
event.description: The Supreme Court's affirmation of the National Labor Relations Act of 1935 strengthens the legal framework for collective bargaining and the protection of workers' rights, shaping the labor landscape during the Great Depression.

event.name: Neutrality Act prohibits export of arms and ammunition to belligerents
event.description: The Neutrality Act's prohibition on exporting arms and ammunition to belligerent nations aims to maintain the United States' neutrality and avoid entanglement in international conflicts, reflecting the global tensions leading to World War II.

event.name: Supreme Court upholds constitutionality of the Social Security Act
event.description: The Supreme Court's validation of the Social Security Act establishes a landmark social welfare program, providing financial security for elderly and vulnerable populations during the Great Depression and beyond.

event.name: Japanese planes sink the U.S. gunboat Panay in Chinese waters
event.description: Japanese military aircraft attack and sink the U.S. gunboat Panay in Chinese waters, resulting in diplomatic tensions between the United States and Japan, and highlighting the escalating conflicts in East Asia.

event.name: Munich Pact
event.description: To avert war, Britain and France give in to Hitler's claim to the Sudetenland, the German-populated part of Czechoslovakia. Critics denounce the agreement as 'appeasement.'

event.name: Marian Anderson sings at the Lincoln Memorial
event.description: Denied use of Constitution Hall by the Daughters of the American Revolution, contralto Marian Anderson sings at the Lincoln Memorial before 75,000 people, making a powerful statement against racial discrimination.

event.name: Germany and the Soviet Union sign a non-aggression pact
event.description: Germany and the Soviet Union sign a non-aggression pact, agreeing to divide Poland. This event marks a significant shift in alliances and sets the stage for the outbreak of World War II.

event.name: Germany's invasion of Poland
event.description: Germany invades Poland, triggering the start of World War II. This aggressive action by Germany leads to a global conflict that reshapes the course of history.

event.name: The 18th Amendment (Prohibition) goes into effect
event.description: The 18th Amendment, known as Prohibition, goes into effect, banning the sale and manufacture of all alcoholic beverages in the United States. This led to a significant increase in illegal alcohol production and distribution.

event.name: Black Thursday Stock Market Crash
event.description: On October 24, 1929, known as 'Black Thursday,' a record-breaking crash on the New York Stock Exchange begins several weeks of market panics. This event marked the beginning of the Great Depression, leading to widespread economic hardship.

event.name: Black Tuesday Stock Market Crash
event.description: On October 29, 1929, known as 'Black Tuesday,' the value of the stocks on the New York Stock Market continues its dramatic decline, with approximately 16,410,000 shares, a record number, being sold. This event marks the beginning of the Great Depression, the worst economic crisis in U.S. history.

event.name: Alphonse Capone sentenced for income tax evasion
event.description: Alphonse Capone, the notorious gangster, receives an 11-year prison sentence for income tax evasion, marking the downfall of a prominent figure in organized crime during the Great Depression.

event.name: Establishment of Reconstruction Finance Corporation
event.description: Congress establishes the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on January 22, 1932, aiming to provide federal financial support to the banking systems during the Great Depression, which was a crucial step in stabilizing the economy.

event.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt's acceptance speech for Democratic nomination
event.description: On July 2, 1932, Franklin Delano Roosevelt delivers a speech accepting the Democratic nomination for president, where he pledges 'a new deal for the American people,' setting the stage for his presidency and the New Deal policies.

event.name: Bonus Army march on Washington, DC
event.description: On July 28, 1932, thousands of unemployed World War I veterans and their families, known as the Bonus Army, march on Washington, DC, seeking early payment of previously promised bonus pay, but are denied by Congress, leading to violence and reflecting badly on the Hoover Administration during the Great Depression.

event.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt's Inauguration
event.description: Franklin D. Roosevelt is inaugurated as president with the U.S. banking system all but paralyzed. He declares “there is nothing to fear but fear itself.”

event.name: President Roosevelt orders nationwide bank holiday
event.description: President Roosevelt orders a nationwide “bank holiday” from Monday, March 6 through Thursday, March 9, and then extends it through March 12 to restore public confidence in the banking system.

event.name: First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt's weekly news conferences
event.description: First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt begins her weekly news conferences open only to women journalists, providing a platform for women journalists to engage with the First Lady and discuss important issues.

event.name: Congress special session for economic relief legislation
event.description: Congress begins a special session to approve legislation aimed at economic relief and recovery, leading to the passage of the Emergency Bank Act to restore public confidence in the banking system.

event.name: Reopening of most U.S. banks
event.description: Most U.S. banks successfully reopen after the extended bank holiday, marking a significant step in restoring public confidence in the banking system during the Great Depression.

event.name: President Roosevelt's first informal news conference
event.description: President Roosevelt begins the first of his informal and informative presidential news conferences, providing a direct channel for the public to receive updates and insights during the Great Depression.

event.name: Establishment of the Civil Conservation Corps (CCC)
event.description: The Civil Conservation Corps (CCC) is established, providing jobs in conservation activities for young Americans, contributing to environmental and economic efforts during the Great Depression.

event.name: Passage of the Agricultural Adjustment Act (AAA)
event.description: Congress passes the Agricultural Adjustment Act (AAA) to raise farm prices by encouraging farmers to reduce production, aiming to stabilize the agricultural sector during the Great Depression.

event.name: Passage of the Emergency Farm Mortgage Act
event.description: Congress passes the Emergency Farm Mortgage Act to provide loans to farmers in heavy debt, offering crucial financial support to the agricultural community during the Great Depression.

event.name: Passage of the Federal Emergency Relief Act (FERA)
event.description: Congress passes the Federal Emergency Relief Act (FERA), providing funds to assist state relief programs helping the unemployed, aged, and ill, addressing critical social and economic challenges during the Great Depression.

event.name: Creation of Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA)
event.description: The Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) was created to bring economic development to the Southeast through the construction of numerous dams and hydropower plants, aiming to provide electricity and control flooding in the region.

event.name: Passing of Federal Securities Act
event.description: The Federal Securities Act was passed, requiring companies and stockbrokers to provide full information about new stocks to potential investors, aiming to protect investors from fraudulent practices and promote transparency in the stock market.

event.name: Passing of Home Owners’ Refinancing Act
event.description: The Home Owners’ Refinancing Act was passed, creating the Home Owners’ Loan Corporation (HOLC) to provide loans to homeowners facing the loss of their homes because they cannot make payments, aiming to prevent foreclosures and stabilize the housing market.

event.name: Passing of Farm Credit Act
event.description: The Farm Credit Act was passed, formalizing the earlier-created Farm Credit Administration, which established a system of banking institutions for farmers, aiming to provide them with access to credit and financial stability.

event.name: Passing of Banking Act (Glass-Steagall Act)
event.description: The Banking Act, also known as the Glass-Steagall Act, was passed, establishing the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) insuring individual bank accounts against loss, aiming to restore confidence in the banking system and prevent bank runs.

event.name: Establishment of National Industrial Recovery Act
event.description: The National Industrial Recovery Act was passed, establishing codes of fair practice for industry and business and creating the National Recovery Administration (NRA), aiming to stimulate economic recovery and industrial growth.

event.name: Creation of Public Works Administration (PWA)
event.description: The Public Works Administration (PWA) was created to distribute almost $6 billion between 1933 and 1939 for public works projects, including construction of roads, tunnels, bridges, dams, power plants, and hospitals, aiming to provide employment and stimulate the economy through infrastructure development.

event.name: First Hundred Days
event.description: Congress finishes the special session, an intensive period of lawmaking that becomes known as the First Hundred Days, marking a significant milestone in President Roosevelt's New Deal program.

event.name: Civil Works Administration (CWA)
event.description: President Roosevelt establishes the Civil Works Administration (CWA) to assist unemployed workers through the winter months, providing crucial relief during the Great Depression.

event.name: End of Prohibition
event.description: The 30th state ratifies the 21st Amendment, ending Prohibition, which banned the sale of alcoholic beverages, marking a significant shift in U.S. social and economic policies.

event.name: Farm Mortgage Refinancing Act
event.description: Congress passes the Farm Mortgage Refinancing Act providing $2 billion on loans to refinance farm loans, aiming to alleviate the financial burden on farmers during the Great Depression.

event.name: Security Exchange Act
event.description: Congress passes the Security Exchange Act that prohibits certain activities in stock market trading, sets penalties, and establishes the Securities Exchange Commission (SEC) to oversee stock market trading, aiming to restore confidence in the financial system during the Great Depression.

event.name: Indian Reorganization Act
event.description: Congress passes the Indian Reorganization Act (Wheeler-Howard Act) establishing the cornerstone of New Deal Indian Policy, aiming to reform the governance and economic conditions of Native American reservations during the Great Depression.

event.name: Communications Act
event.description: Congress passes the Communications Act that creates the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to oversee the nation’s mass-communication industry, marking a significant development in the regulation of communication during the Great Depression.

event.name: Passing of National Housing Act and Creation of FHA
event.description: On June 28, 1934, Congress passed the National Housing Act, which created the Federal Housing Administration (FHA) to assist homeowners in buying new houses and to stimulate the construction industry. This was the final piece of legislation passed under the First New Deal initiated in March 1933.

event.name: Passing of Emergency Relief Appropriation Act and Creation of WPA
event.description: On April 8, 1935, Congress passed the Emergency Relief Appropriation Act, establishing the Works Progress Administration (WPA) and allocating nearly $5 billion for work relief projects, including the construction of various public facilities. This marked the beginning of the Second New Deal.

event.name: Passing of Soil Conservation Act and Establishment of SCS
event.description: On April 27, 1935, Congress passed the Soil Conservation Act, which led to the establishment of the Soil Conservation Service (SCS) to aid farmers affected by drought and soil erosion during the Great Depression.

event.name: Creation of Resettlement Administration (RA)
event.description: On April 30, 1935, President Roosevelt created the Resettlement Administration (RA) to assist poor farmers in improving the use of their lands or relocating to better lands. The agency also initiated a major photodocumentary project of the Depression.

event.name: Establishment of Rural Electrification Administration (REA)
event.description: On May 11, 1935, President Roosevelt established the Rural Electrification Administration (REA) with the aim of providing inexpensive electricity to rural areas, significantly improving the quality of life for rural communities.

event.name: Supreme Court rules National Industrial Recovery Act unconstitutional
event.description: On May 27, 1935, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled the National Industrial Recovery Act unconstitutional in the case of Schechter Poultry Corporation v. United States. This decision had a significant impact on labor unions and became known as 'Black Monday.'

event.name: Establishment of National Youth Administration (NYA)
event.description: On June 26, 1935, President Roosevelt created the National Youth Administration (NYA) to provide part-time jobs to high school and college students as well as other unemployed youth, aiming to alleviate the impact of the Great Depression on the younger generation.

event.name: Commencement of Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC)
event.description: On July 1, 1935, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) began operation, playing a crucial role in stabilizing the banking system by insuring bank deposits, thus restoring public confidence in the financial sector during the Great Depression.

event.name: Passage of National Labor Relations Act (Wagner Act)
event.description: On July 5, 1935, Congress passed the National Labor Relations Act, commonly known as the Wagner Act, to protect the rights of workers to organize and collectively bargain with employers. The act also aimed to address unfair business practices, marking a significant milestone in labor rights during the Great Depression.

event.name: Establishment of Federal One program
event.description: On August 2, 1935, the Federal One program was established as part of the Works Progress Administration (WPA) to provide employment opportunities for the unemployed in various fields such as music, theater, writing, and art, contributing to the cultural and artistic development during the Great Depression.

event.name: Passing of the Social Security Act
event.description: The Social Security Act was passed by Congress, establishing a program of social insurance to aid the unemployed, the elderly in retirement, needy children and mothers, and the blind.

event.name: Passing of the Banking Act
event.description: Congress passed the Banking Act, which strengthened the Federal Reserve System.

event.name: Passing of the Wealth Tax Act
event.description: The Wealth Tax Act was passed by Congress, creating higher tax rates for the wealthy and corporate and inheritance taxes.

event.name: Establishment of the Committee of Industrial Organizations
event.description: Labor leader John L. Lewis establishes the Committee of Industrial Organizations to represent semi-skilled and unskilled laborers of the mass production industries.

event.name: United States v. Butler ruling on the Agricultural Adjustment Act
event.description: The U.S. Supreme Court in United States v. Butler rules the Agricultural Adjustment Act is unconstitutional.

event.name: Passing of the Flood Control Act
event.description: Congress passes the Flood Control Act in response to massive floods in Ohio and Mississippi.

event.name: Sit-down strikes at General Motors plants
event.description: Sit-down strikes shutdown seven General Motors plants in Flint, Michigan. The company will give in to worker demands by February 11, 1937.

event.name: Roosevelt's 'court packing plan' proposal
event.description: On February 5, 1937, Roosevelt introduces a proposal known as the “court packing plan” to reorganize the U.S. Supreme Court, which sparks substantial public opposition and political controversy.

event.name: U.S. Supreme Court upholds the constitutionality of the Social Security Act
event.description: On May 24, 1937, the U.S. Supreme Court upholds the constitutionality of the Social Security Act, a pivotal decision that secures the future of social welfare programs in the United States.

event.name: Passage of the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenancy Act
event.description: On July 22, 1937, Congress passes the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenancy Act, providing low-interest loans to tenant farmers, farm laborers, and small landowners, offering crucial support to those affected by the Dust Bowl and agricultural challenges during the Great Depression.

event.name: Establishment of the Bonneville Power Administration
event.description: On August 20, 1937, the Bonneville Power Act establishes the Bonneville Power Administration to market public power in the Pacific Northwest, playing a key role in the development of public utilities and infrastructure during the Great Depression.

event.name: Creation of the Farm Security Administration
event.description: On September 1, 1937, Roosevelt creates the Farm Security Administration, absorbing the Resettlement Administration including the photography project, aiming to address rural poverty and provide assistance to farmers and agricultural workers during the Great Depression.

event.name: Passing of the National Housing Act
event.description: The National Housing Act, also known as the Wagner-Steagall Housing Act, was passed by Congress, creating the U.S. Housing Authority to oversee the construction of low-cost housing.

event.name: Passing of the New Agricultural Adjustment Act
event.description: Congress passes the new Agricultural Adjustment Act, providing new price supports for farmers and promoting conservation practices.

event.name: Passing of the Food, Drug, and Cosmetics Act
event.description: Congress passes the Food, Drug, and Cosmetics Act to regulate the safety and labeling of food, drugs, and cosmetics.

event.name: Passing of the Fair Labor Standards Act
event.description: The Fair Labor Standards Act is passed, placing legal protections over child labor, minimum wages, and maximum hours. This act marks the conclusion of the Second New Deal.

event.name: The War of the Worlds Radio Broadcast
event.description: Orson Welles’ Mercury Theatre of the Air broadcasts a radio adaptation of H. G. Wells’ 1898 novel The War of the Worlds, causing widespread panic and mass hysteria across the United States.

event.name: Start of the Food Stamp Program
event.description: The Food Stamp program begins, aiming to provide assistance to low-income families during the Great Depression.

event.name: Social Security Act Amendments
event.description: Congress passes the Social Security Act Amendments, adding old age and survivors’ insurance benefits for dependents and survivors, expanding the social welfare system during the Great Depression.

event.name: President Roosevelt announces U.S. preparations for World War II
event.description: On July 9, 1941, President Roosevelt announced extensive preparations in case of U.S. entrance into World War II, signaling the country's readiness for potential involvement in the global conflict.

event.name: Japan bombs U.S. military installation at Pearl Harbor
event.description: On December 7, 1941, Japan bombed the U.S. military installation at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, leading the United States to enter World War II in both Europe and the Pacific, marking a pivotal moment in the war.

event.name: Establishment of the War Production Board
event.description: On January 16, 1942, the War Production Board was established to direct war mobilization, playing a crucial role in coordinating the industrial efforts for the war.

event.name: Death of Franklin Roosevelt
event.description: On April 12, 1945, Franklin Roosevelt suddenly died at 63 years of age from a cerebral hemorrhage, marking the end of his presidency and a significant loss for the nation.

event.name: Wall Street Crash
event.description: The American stock market collapses, marking the beginning of the Great Depression. The Dow Jones Industrial Average reaches its peak in September 1929 at 381.17, but does not recover until 1954. It hits a Depression-era low of 41.22 in 1932.

event.name: Smoot-Hawley Tariff
event.description: Congress passes the Smoot-Hawley Tariff, significantly increasing import duties to protect American manufacturers from foreign competition. Although it has little impact on the American economy, it worsens the crisis in Europe.

event.name: New York's Bank of the United States collapses
event.description: In 1931, New York's Bank of the United States collapses, marking the largest bank failure in American history, leading to the disappearance of $200 million in deposits and leaving the bank's customers in a dire situation.

event.name: Unemployment at 24.1%
event.description: In 1932, unemployment averages 24.1% for the year, reflecting the severe economic challenges faced during the Great Depression.

event.name: Roosevelt Elected
event.description: In 1932, Democrat Franklin D. Roosevelt defeats incumbent Republican President Herbert Hoover in a landslide victory, marking a significant shift in American politics during the Great Depression.

event.name: Unemployment at 24.9%
event.description: In 1933, unemployment averages 24.9% for the year, indicating the prolonged economic hardship experienced during the Great Depression.

event.name: Radio Priest Charles Coughlin's Broadcast
event.description: In 1931, 'Radio Priest' Charles Coughlin's weekly broadcast garners an average of 30 to 45 million listeners, exerting significant influence during the Great Depression.

event.name: Roosevelt Inauguration
event.description: Franklin D. Roosevelt is inaugurated as the 32nd President of the United States, marking the beginning of his presidency during the Great Depression.

event.name: Townsend Proposes Pension Plan
event.description: Dr. Francis Townsend proposes state-funded pensions for the elderly in order to stimulate consumption and employment, addressing the economic challenges of the Great Depression.

event.name: Upton Sinclair Publishes Treatise
event.description: Upton Sinclair publishes 'I, Governor of California and How I Ended Poverty: A True Story of the Future', outlining the communitarian movement EPIC (End Poverty in California) and its vision for addressing poverty during the Great Depression.

event.name: Townsend Plan Incorporated
event.description: Dr. Francis Townsend formally incorporates Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd., to lead the Townsend Plan movement, which aimed to provide financial assistance to the elderly during the Great Depression.

event.name: Share Our Wealth Society Founded
event.description: Huey Long founds the Share Our Wealth society, advocating outright seizure of the 'excess fortunes' of the rich to redistribute to the poor, as a response to the economic hardships faced during the Great Depression.

event.name: Longshoremen Strike
event.description: A West Coast longshoremen's strike, conducted with significant aid from the Communist Party, paralyzes shipping and trade in California, Oregon, and Washington. The strike ends with a victory for the longshoremen's union, marking a significant event during the Great Depression era.

event.name: Upton Sinclair Wins Primary
event.description: Upton Sinclair wins the Democratic gubernatorial primary in California with a surprising groundswell of support for his EPIC movement, securing a runaway victory.

event.name: Charles Coughlin Establishes the National Union for Social Justice
event.description: Father Charles Coughlin, known as 'The Radio Priest,' establishes the National Union for Social Justice.

event.name: Upton Sinclair Defeated
event.description: Upton Sinclair is soundly defeated by conservative Republican Frank Merriam for governor of California after a two-month campaign marked by ferocious attacks on his EPIC movement.

event.name: Townsend Support Grows
event.description: The Townsend Clubs, representing more than 2 million members, gain support from over 5,000 clubs nationwide. 25 million Americans have signed petitions to back the Townsend Plan in Washington.

event.name: Huey Long Support Grows
event.description: Huey Long's Share Our Wealth society expands to 27,000 clubs nationwide, with a mailing list of 7.5 million Americans, indicating a growing support for his movement.

event.name: Huey Long Assassinated
event.description: Huey Long is assassinated inside the Louisiana Capitol Building, marking the end of his influential political career.

event.name: Roosevelt Reelected
event.description: Franklin D. Roosevelt is reelected to a second term as president in a landslide victory, winning all states except Maine and Vermont, indicating strong public support for his policies during the Great Depression.

event.name: Nazi Rally in New York City
event.description: On February 20, 1939, the German-American Bund organized a large rally of fascist sympathizers at Madison Square Garden in New York City. The event, led by Fritz Kuhn, aimed to promote 'True Americanism' and included anti-Semitic rhetoric and criticism of President Franklin Roosevelt and the New Deal.

event.name: Japanese Attack on Pearl Harbor
event.description: The Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941, marked the entry of the United States into World War II.

event_translation.name: 허버트 후버의 미국 대통령 취임
event_translation.description: 허버트 후버는 미국의 31대 대통령으로 취임하지만, 그의 자유주의적인 경제 방침은 대공황을 완화하는 데 도움이 되지 않았고, 악명을 얻게 되었다.

event_translation.name: 월가 대공황 이전 고점 회복 25년
event_translation.description: 이 날 이후, 주식 시장이 월가 대공황 이전 고점을 회복하는 데 25년이 걸렸으며, 이는 대공황의 장기적인 영향을 나타낸다.

event_translation.name: 블랙 목요일 주식 시장 대폭락
event_translation.description: 블랙 목요일은 주식 시장 대폭락의 시작을 촉발시켰으며, 이로 인해 나라와 세계 전체가 대공황에 빠졌다. 주식 가격은 11% 하락하여 중대한 경제 침체로 이어졌다.

event_translation.name: 블랙 월요일 주식 시장 대폭락
event_translation.description: 블랙 월요일에 주식 가격이 13% 하락하여 주식 시장 대폭락의 영향을 악화시키고 대공황의 시작에 더 기여하였다.

event_translation.name: 블랙 투즈데이
event_translation.description: 1929년 10월 29일에 주식 시장이 대폭락하여 12%의 손실과 1600만 주의 거래가 이뤄졌다. 은행의 개입으로 인해 공포가 가중되었다.

event_translation.name: 사이드웨이 트레이딩 시작
event_translation.description: 1929년 11월 23일에 주식 시장이 바닥을 치고 나서 측면 거래를 시작했다. 후버 대통령의 경제적 미래에 대한 발언이 곧 오는 곤경에 대한 무감각함을 더했다.

event_translation.name: Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act Signed
event_translation.description: 1930년 6월 17일, 후버 대통령이 Smoot-Hawley 관세법에 서명했다. 900가지 다른 수입품에 대한 세금을 인상했다. 목표는 농부들을 지원하는 것이었지만, 국제무역에 영향을 미치고 유럽에서 문제를 일으켰다. 이로 인해 국제무역이 감소하고 경제적 어려움이 생겼다.

event_translation.name: 테네시 주 은행 파산
event_translation.description: 테네시 주 은행이 파산하여 관련 은행들의 파산을 일으키고 은행 시스템의 취약점에 기여했다. 이는 경제에 상당한 영향을 미쳐 은행 파산과 경기 침체로 이어졌다.

event_translation.name: 미국 은행 실패
event_translation.description: 1931년 12월 11일, 미국 은행이 실패하여 미국 역사상 가장 큰 은행 파산을 일으켰다. 이 사건은 대공황 기간의 경제 위기에 상당한 영향을 미쳤다.

event_translation.name: 대통령 루즈벨트 당선
event_translation.description: 민주당 후보 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트가 허버트 후버를 압도하여 미국 대통령으로 당선된다. 루즈벨트는 22,800,000 표를 획득했고, 후버는 15,750,000 표를 획득했다. 실업률: 23.6%.

event_translation.name: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트의 '뉴딜' 연설
event_translation.description: 1932년 대통령 후보인 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트가 경제 회복을 위한 계획을 공개하기 위해 '뉴딜' 연설을 하였다.

event_translation.name: 1932년 수입법
event_translation.description: 후버 대통령이 1932년 수입법에 서명하여 최상위 소득세율을 63%로 인상시켰다. 신뢰를 회복하고 연방 적자를 줄일 것으로 믿었지만, 세금 인상은 실제로 대공황을 더 악화시키게 되었다.

event_translation.name: 대통령 루즈벨트의 첫 100일
event_translation.description: 루즈벨트 대통령이 그의 '첫 100일'을 시작하여 대공황 대책으로 15개의 법률을 신속히 도입하기 시작했다.

event_translation.name: 은행 휴일
event_translation.description: 루즈벨트 대통령이 대공황 기간의 경제 위기에 대처하기 위해 모든 은행을 휴일로 폐쇄했다.

event_translation.name: 비상 은행법
event_translation.description: 루즈벨트 대통령이 신속히 미국의 모든 은행을 폐쇄하여 추가 경제 실패를 막고 뉴딜을 시작했다.

event_translation.name: 화력 속담 시작
event_translation.description: 루즈벨트 대통령이 그의 집에서의 방송 시리즈 '화력 속담'을 시작하여 정부의 대공황 대책을 나라에 업데이트하기 위해 시작했다.

event_translation.name: 정부 경제법
event_translation.description: 정부 경제법이 도입되어 대공황 기간의 뉴딜을 지원하기 위해 정부 지출을 줄이려는 시도를 했다.

event_translation.name: 맥주-와인 수입세법
event_translation.description: 맥주-와인 수입세법이 도입되어 술 판매에 세금을 부과하여 금지 시대를 종식시키고 수입을 늘렸다.

event_translation.name: 프랜시스 타운젠드 박사의 연금 계획 제안
event_translation.description: 프랜시스 타운젠드 박사가 고령자를 위한 주도재정 연금 계획을 제안했다. 이는 고용과 소비를 촉진하는 방법으로 제안되었다.

event_translation.name: 시민 공사 행정에 의한 400만 개의 건설 일자리 창출
event_translation.description: 시민 공사 행정이 400만 개의 건설 일자리를 만들어 대공황 기간 동안 고용을 제공했다. 한편으로 오클라호마와 주변 주에서 먼지 폭풍이 일어나 농부들에게 어려움을 초래했다.

event_translation.name: 프랜시스 타운젠드 박사에 의한 노인 회전 연금 주식회사 설립
event_translation.description: 프랜시스 타운젠드 박사가 공식적으로 노인들이 대공황 기간에 직면한 경제적 도전에 대응하기 위해 노인 회전 연금 주식회사를 설립했다.

event_translation.name: 골드 보유법의 도입
event_translation.description: 골드 보유법이 도입되어 금 가격이 두 배로 오르고 사립 소유가 금지되어 대공황 기간의 경제와 금융 환경에 영향을 미쳤다.

event_translation.name: 휴이 롱에 의한 우리 부의 사회 설립
event_translation.description: 휴이 롱이 '부자들의 과다한 재산'을 가난한 이들에게 재분배하기 위해 우리 부의 사회를 설립했다. 이는 대공황 기간의 경제적 불평등에 대응하는 것을 목표로 한다.

event_translation.name: 블랙 선데이 먼지 폭풍
event_translation.description: 1934년 4월 15일, 미국 역사상 최악의 먼지 폭풍인 블랙 선데이가 대서양을 초토화시켜 심각한 생태학적, 농업적 피해를 일으켰다.

event_translation.name: 토양 보전법
event_translation.description: 1934년 4월 15일, 루즈벨트 대통령이 토양 보전법을 도입하여 농부들이 지속 가능한 농업 관행을 배우고, 블랙 선데이 먼지 폭풍과 같은 사건으로 인한 생태학적 파괴를 대비하고자 했다.

event_translation.name: 연방 주택 관리국과 증권 거래위원회
event_translation.description: 1934년 6월 27일, 연방 주택 관리국은 모기지 보험을 제공하고, 증권 거래위원회가 주식 시장을 규제하기 위해 설립되어 경제를 안정화하고 미래의 금융 위기를 예방하려 했다.

event_translation.name: 타운젠드 계획과 우리의 부의 사회
event_translation.description: 1935년, 타운젠드 계획과 우리의 부의 사회에 대한 지지가 크게 증가했으며, 수백만 명의 미국인이 대공황의 과제에 대처하기 위한 경제 개혁을 옹호했다.

event_translation.name: 이주 정부
event_translation.description: 1935년 4월 30일, 이주 정부는 농부들에게 훈련과 대출을 제공하여 대공황 기간 동안의 농업 및 농촌 지역의 과제에 대처하고자 했다.

event_translation.name: 사업 진행 행정부
event_translation.description: 1935년 5월 6일, 사업 진행 행정부가 설립되어 수백만 명의 사람들을 고용 위기에 대처하고, 대공황 기간 동안 경제를 촉진하기 위해 다양한 공공 사업을 수행했다.

event_translation.name: 농촌 전기화법 시행
event_translation.description: 농촌 전기화법은 농장들이 전기를 생산하고, 농촌 지역에 전기를 공급하여 농부들의 삶을 향상시키기 위해 시행되었다.

event_translation.name: 루즈벨트 대통령 제2대 대통령 재선출
event_translation.description: 루즈벨트 대통령이 제2대 대통령 재선출되어 대공황의 도전과 그에 따른 영향에 대처하기 위한 노력을 계속했다.

event_translation.name: The Grapes of Wrath의 출판
event_translation.description: 1939년 4월 14일, 존 스타인벡이 그의 소설 The Grapes of Wrath를 출판하여 1930년대의 고난을 오클라호마 출신 이주 가족을 통해 묘사한다.

event_translation.name: 1920년대 경제 붐
event_translation.description: 1929년 1월부터 6월까지의 기간은 1920년대 경제 붐으로 알려진 중요한 경제 붐을 보였으며, 역대 최고의 이윤, 소매 매출, 건설 착수 및 주식 시장 이익이 있었다. 그러나 1928년의 밀의 과잉으로 인해 상품 시장과 농부의 소득에 압력이 가해졌다.

event_translation.name: 미니 주식 시장 대폭락
event_translation.description: 미국 연방준비제도가 과도한 투기에 대해 경고한 후 미니 주식 시장 대폭락이 발생했다. 국립시티은행이 주식 시장에 2천5백만 달러의 신용을 투입함으로써 대폭락이 두 날 후에 회피되었다.

event_translation.name: 1929년 농업 마케팅법
event_translation.description: 1929년 농업 마케팅법이 시행되어 어려움을 겪는 농부들에게 약 1억 달러의 긴급 대출을 제공했다.

event_translation.name: 다우존스 산업평균 최고치
event_translation.description: 다우존스 산업평균은 381.17에 도달하여 1954년 11월 23일까지 다시 도달하지 못할 수준에 이르렀다.

event_translation.name: 1929년 월가 대폭락 시작
event_translation.description: 악명높은 1929년 월가 대폭락이 시작되어 주식 가치가 크게 하락하고 대공황의 시작이 되었다.

event_translation.name: 블랙 화요일
event_translation.description: '블랙 화요일'에 뉴욕 증권거래소가 붕괴되어 다우존스 지수가 12% 이상 하락하여 대공황의 가장 파괴적인 사건 중 하나로 기록되었다.

event_translation.name: 주식 시장 최저점
event_translation.description: 주식 시장이 198.60에 최저점을 찍은 뒤 1930년 4월까지 이어지는 곰 시장이 시작되어 대공황의 심각성에 기여했다.

event_translation.name: 다우존스 이후 보조 폐장 최고치
event_translation.description: 다우존스가 294.07에 이르러 1931년 4월에 심한 하락이 시작되기 전까지 장기간의 침체가 이어져 대공황의 지속적인 경제적 도전을 반영했다.

event_translation.name: 자동차 판매 감소
event_translation.description: 자동차 판매가 1928년 수준을 밑돌며 소비자 지출에 대한 대공황의 지속적인 경제 침체와 영향을 나타냈다.

event_translation.name: Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act passage
event_translation.description: 스무트-할리 관세법이 통과되었을 때, 농산물 거래의 붕괴를 통해 주로 세계 경제를 약화시키고 농부들에게 대출을 많이 한 은행들을 압박했다. 이는 제조업품의 무역을 더욱 감소시켜 해고와 기업 이익 감소로 이어져 경제를 약화시켰다.

event_translation.name: 1930 German federal election
event_translation.description: 1930년 독일 연방 선거는 나치당과 공산당이 큰 성과를 거두어 라이히스타그에서 두 번째로 큰 정당이 되었다. 재임 중인 민주주의 바이마르 연립을 이루는 정당들은 참혹한 패배를 입었다.

event_translation.name: Creditanstalt insolvency
event_translation.description: 크레딧안스톨트는 오스트리아의 주요 은행으로 다양한 산업에 주요 지분을 가졌으나, 다른 세 은행의 파산으로 인한 부채를 강제로 떠안아 파산하게 되었고, 중앙 유럽 전역에 은행 파산의 연쇄 효과를 일으켰다. 크레딧안스톨트의 붕괴로 프랑스 은행, 벨기에 국립은행, 네덜란드 은행, 스위스 국립은행은 그들의 금 보유액을 위해 미국 달러를 달려들기 시작했고, 이로 인해 연방준비제도는 금 기준을 유지하기 위해 이자율을 1.5%에서 3.5%로 인상해야 했으며, 결과적으로 미국 내 은행 파산의 두 번째 라운드와 함께 불황을 더욱 심화시켰다.

event_translation.name: 브리튼이 황금 표준을 떠나는 것
event_translation.description: 1931년 9월 21일, 브리튼은 황금 표준을 떠나 25%의 파운드 스털링 가치 하락을 야기했다. 재앙을 예고했음에도 불구하고, 이탈은 영국 경제에 이로웠다. 수출이 더 경쟁력을 갖게 되었다. 또한 이 사건으로 잉글랜드 은행은 화폐 창조에 참여하고 이자율을 낮출 수 있었으며, 이는 경제 성장과 실업률 감소로 이어졌다.

event_translation.name: 영국 총선, 1931년
event_translation.description: 1931년 10월 27일, 영국 총선이 열려 노동당을 파멸시키고 보수당에 압도적인 승리를 안겼다.

event_translation.name: 재건 금융 기구 창설
event_translation.description: 재건 금융 기구는 연방준비제도의 일부가 아니었지만 장기적으로 지속 가능한 곤경에 처한 금융 기관들에게 20억 달러를 대출하기 위해 창설되었다. 1941년까지 RFC는 은행, 철도, 주택 협회뿐만 아니라 주지방 정부에도 95억 달러 가량을 대출했다.

event_translation.name: 1932년 세입법 통과
event_translation.description: 1932년 세입법이 공포되어 개인소득세, 법인소득세 및 다양한 상품의 판매세를 인상시켰다.

event_translation.name: 다우존스 산업지수 최저점 도달
event_translation.description: 다우존스 산업지수가 41.22로 역사상 최저치를 기록하며 1929년 9월의 최고치 대비 89%의 하락을 나타내었다.

event_translation.name: 1932년 7월 독일 연방 선거
event_translation.description: 아돌프 히틀러가 이끄는 나치당이 라이히스타그에서 최대 정당이 되었지만 다수를 차지하지는 못했다. 공산당과 나치당의 연합 강도로 인해 처음으로 독일에 반민주주의적 다수가 생겼다.

event_translation.name: 1932년 11월 독일 연방 선거
event_translation.description: 1990년까지 이어진 마지막 자유롭고 공정한 독일 전체 선거가 열렸다. 나치당에 소소한 저항이 있었지만, 1933년 3월 다음 선거를 앞두고 대규모 폭력과 위협 캠페인이 시작되었다. 그럼에도 불구하고 공산당과 나치당 사이의 반민주주의적 다수는 가깝게 유지되었다.

event_translation.name: 1932년 미국 선거
event_translation.description: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트가 민주당 후보로 대통령에 32대로 당선되었고, 민주당은 의회 양원에서 대규모 다수를 획득했다.

event_translation.name: 미시간 무기한 은행 휴일 선언
event_translation.description: 미시간은 미국에서 첫 번째로 무기한 은행 휴일을 선언하여, 디트로이트의 두 대형 은행인 포드 자동차 회사가 두 은행에 예금을 모두 철수할 경우 파산 위기를 막기 위해 이 조치가 취해졌다. 이로 인해 대규모 실업과 경제 불안이 초래될 것을 우려하여 이 조치가 취해졌다.

event_translation.name: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트의 취임식
event_translation.description: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트가 미국의 32번째 대통령으로 취임되어 대공황 시기의 대통령직을 시작함을 나타냄.

event_translation.name: 1933년 3월 독일 연방 선거
event_translation.description: 나치당이 독일 연방 선거에서 좁은 다수를 획득하여 독일에서 권력을 확고히 하는 중요한 단계를 나타냄.

event_translation.name: 행정명령 2009번이 은행 활동 중단
event_translation.description: 행정명령 2009번이 뉴욕시 주요 은행들에 대한 재압력에 대응하여 한 주간 모든 은행 활동을 중단시키고 대공황의 심화를 막으려 함.

event_translation.name: 긴급 은행법 시행
event_translation.description: 긴급 은행법이 시행되어 은행 시스템을 재구성하고 연방 예금 보험공사(FDIC)를 설립하여 대공황 시기의 은행 시스템에 대한 신뢰를 회복시키려 함.

event_translation.name: 1933년 경제법 서명
event_translation.description: 논란이 많은 1933년 경제법이 서명되어 경제 위기 시기에 정부 지출을 줄이고 예산을 균형있게 하려 함.

event_translation.name: 시민 보전부 창설
event_translation.description: 대공황 시기의 고용과 보전 노력을 위해 뉴딜 프로그램의 일환으로 시민 보전부가 창설됨.

event_translation.name: 행정명령 6102번이 금 보유 금지
event_translation.description: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트 대통령이 행정명령 6102번을 발표하여 금화, 금괴, 증권의 보유를 금지하여 대공황 시기의 경제 안정화를 위한 조치로 채택됨.

event_translation.name: 농업 조정법 시행
event_translation.description: 농업 조정법이 시행되어 대공황 시기의 농산물 과잉을 줄이고 농산물 가격을 높이려 함.

event_translation.name: 1933년 증권법 시행
event_translation.description: 증권법이 시행되어 모든 금융 증권의 매매를 등록하도록 하여 대공황 시기의 내부자거래를 막고 거래 위험을 줄이려 함.

event_translation.name: 시민 공사 행정부 창설
event_translation.description: 시민 공사 행정부가 창설되어 400만 명 이상의 사람들을 고용하고 대공황 시기의 일자리 프로그램에 자금을 배정함.

event_translation.name: 국가적으로 금지법 폐지
event_translation.description: 국가적으로 금지법이 폐지되어 미국의 술 금지 시대가 종료되고 조직 범죄, 고용, 주세 수입에 미치는 영향이 나타남.

event_translation.name: 1929년 주식 시장 대란
event_translation.description: 1929년 주식 시장 대란은 블랙 목요일로도 알려져 있으며 주식 가격이 즉시 11% 하락하면서 시작되었다. 월가 은행가들이 주식을 사들였지만 시장이 마감될 때까지 2%밖에 손실이 나지 않았다. 이어진 며칠 동안 주식 가격은 계속 변동하였다.

event_translation.name: 허버트 후버 대통령 취임
event_translation.description: 허버트 후버는 1929년 3월 4일에 대통령으로 취임하였다. 그의 자유주의적 경제 정책은 대공황을 막는 데 별다른 성과를 내지 못했다. 그는 자유 시장 경제를 신봉하고 상위 소득세율을 25%에서 24%로 낮추었다.

event_translation.name: 다우 지수 381.7 포인트로 최고치 마감
event_translation.description: 1929년 9월 3일, 다우 지수는 381.7 포인트로 최고치를 기록하였다. 주식 시장은 다음 25년 동안 이전 대란 이전 수준으로 돌아가지 않았다.

event_translation.name: 블랙 먼데이
event_translation.description: 1929년 10월 28일, 주가가 13% 하락하여 악명 높은 블랙 먼데이를 기록하였다. 이는 1929년 주식 시장 대란 중 가장 유명한 사건 중 하나이다.

event_translation.name: 블랙 투즈데이 마켓 크래시
event_translation.description: 블랙 투즈데이에 시장은 또 다른 12%를 잃었고, 사상 최대 1600만 주가 거래되었다. 은행의 개입으로 인해 공포가 더욱 악화되었고, 중대한 경제 침체로 이어졌다.

event_translation.name: 주식 시장 바닥
event_translation.description: 주식 시장은 바닥을 치고 측면으로 거래를 시작하여 대공황의 중요한 지점을 표시했다.

event_translation.name: 수프 주방
event_translation.description: 미국 부통령 찰스 커티스의 자매 돌리 갠은 1930년 12월 27일 새벽부터 미국 사회에 대대적인 영향을 미친 대공황을 반영하여 구제군 수프 주방에서 주방을 도와주었다.

event_translation.name: Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act Signing
event_translation.description: 1930년, 후버 대통령이 Smoot-Hawley 관세법을 서명했는데, 이 법은 900가지 물품에 대한 세금을 인상시켰다. 초기에는 농부들을 돕기 위해 의도되었으나, 결국은 다른 많은 제품에 관세를 부과하고 국제 무역의 붕괴로 이어지게 되었다.

event_translation.name: Department of Veterans Affairs Creation
event_translation.description: 1930년 7월 21일, 후버 대통령이 미국 전쟁 참전 군인들에게 지원과 서비스를 제공하기 위해 미국 전쟁 참전 군인처를 설립했다. 이것은 제1차 세계대전 이후의 군인들의 요구를 해결하는 데 중요한 한 걸음이었다.

event_translation.name: 테네시 은행 파산
event_translation.description: 1930년 11월 7일 테네시 은행의 파산으로 이어진 계열 은행들의 붕괴는 이후 몇 일 동안 악화되는 경제 상황에 기여하여, 미국 은행 시스템의 취약점은 전국의 은행 중 3분의 1만 연방준비제도의 일원이었던 점이 상황을 악화시켜 은행 단체행동과 대규모 파산을 야기시켰다.

event_translation.name: 미국 은행 파산
event_translation.description: 1930년 12월 11일, 당시 미국에서 4번째로 큰 은행이었던 미국 은행의 파산은 역사상 최대 규모의 은행 파산을 나타내었다. 이 사건은 경제 위기를 더욱 심화시켜 중요한 예산 적자, 경제의 8.5% 축소, 그리고 8.7%의 실업률 상승으로 이어졌다.

event_translation.name: 1932년 수입법
event_translation.description: 1932년 6월 6일 후버 대통령이 1932년 수입법에 서명하여 연방 적자를 줄이려고 최상위 소득세율을 63%로 인상했지만 대공황 기간에 경제에 부정적인 영향을 미쳤다.

event_translation.name: 다우 존스 산업평균 지수가 41.22에서 최저점을 기록
event_translation.description: 1932년 7월 8일, 다우 존스 산업평균 지수는 41.22로 하락하여 1929년 9월 주가 대 폭락 이전 수준에서 90% 하락을 나타내었다. 이 사건은 대공황이 주식 시장에 미친 영향의 심각성을 상징화했다.

event_translation.name: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트가 긴급 은행법으로 뉴딜을 시작
event_translation.description: 1933년 3월 9일, 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트 대통령은 긴급 은행법으로 뉴딜을 시작하였으며, 이 법은 대공황 기간 동안 미국의 모든 은행을 일시적으로 폐쇄하여 은행 시스템을 안정화하는 것을 목표로 하였다.

event_translation.name: 정부 경제법이 뉴딜 자금 조달을 위해 정부 지출을 줄임
event_translation.description: 1933년 3월 20일에 시행된 정부 경제법은 뉴딜 계획을 자금 조달하기 위해 정부 지출을 줄이는 것을 목표로 하였으며, 대공황 기간의 경제적 도전에 대한 정부의 노력을 반영하였다.

event_translation.name: 맥주-와인 수입세법이 금지 종료 및 주류 판매세 도입
event_translation.description: 1933년 3월 22일, 맥주-와인 수입세법이 통과되어 금지를 종료하고 대공황 기간 동안 정부의 수입을 위해 주류 판매에 세금을 도입하였다.

event_translation.name: 시민 보전 군사 (CCC)가 공공 지역 유지보수를 위해 노동자를 고용
event_translation.description: 시민 보전 군사 (CCC)는 1933년 3월 31일에 뉴딜의 일환으로 출범하여 300만 명의 노동자를 고용하여 공공 지역의 유지보수를 담당하였으며, 대공황 기간 동안 경제를 촉진하기 위한 정부의 노력을 반영하였다.

event_translation.name: FDR의 금 표준 포기
event_translation.description: 1933년 4월 19일, FDR은 금 표준을 포기하고 사립 금을 달러로 환전하도록 명령하여 금에 대한 동행을 멈추었다.

event_translation.name: 농업 조정법
event_translation.description: 1933년 5월 11일, 농업 조정법이 제정되어 농부들에게 작물을 제한하고 가격을 높이기 위해 농업 위기에 대응하는 조치로 농부들에게 보상을 지급하기로 되었다.

event_translation.name: 긴급 농지 모기지법
event_translation.description: 1933년 5월 12일, 대공황 기간 동안 판매를 막기 위해 농지를 구제하기 위해 대공황 농지 모기지법이 대출을 제공했다.

event_translation.name: 테네시 강 계획법
event_translation.description: 1933년 5월 12일, 미국에서 가장 가난한 지역에 발전소를 건설하기 위해 테네시 강 계획법이 통과되었다.

event_translation.name: 국가 경제 회복 행정부
event_translation.description: 1933년 6월 14일, 국가 경제 회복 행정부가 설립되어 대공황 기간 동안 아동 노동을 금지하고 최저 임금을 제정하고 일일 근로시간을 8시간으로 제한하고 노동조합이 사업주와 다툴 수 있도록 허용되었다.

event_translation.name: 긴급 철도 운송법
event_translation.description: 1933년 6월 15일, 국가 철도 시스템을 조정하기 위해 긴급 철도 운송법이 제정되었다.

event_translation.name: 시민 공사 행정부의 창설
event_translation.description: 시민 공사 행정부가 창설되어 대공황 시기 실업 문제 해결을 위해 400만 개의 건설 일자리를 제공했다. 이 개혁은 경제를 촉진하고 광범위한 실업 위기에 대처하기 위한 것이었다.

event_translation.name: 금 보유법
event_translation.description: 금 보유법이 통과되어 대공황 시기 금의 규제와 가치에 중대한 변화를 가져왔다. 이로써 금의 사유 소유가 금지되었고 가격은 두 배로 올랐다.

event_translation.name: 검은 일요일 먼지 폭풍
event_translation.description: 대공황 시기 중 가장 심각한 먼지 폭풍인 '검은 일요일'이 발생하여 FDR은 환경 파괴와 지속 가능한 농업 방법을 촉진하기 위해 토양 보전법을 통과시켰다.

event_translation.name: 연방 주택 관리청의 연방 모기지 보험 제공
event_translation.description: 연방 주택 관리청은 주택 시장을 부흥시키고 미국인들에게 가격이 적은 주택을 제공하기 위해 연방 모기지 보험을 제공했다. 이는 대공황 기간 동안 경제를 촉진하고 주택 위기에 대처하기 위한 뉴딜 프로그램의 중요한 구성 요소였다.

event_translation.name: 증권 거래위원회가 주식 시장을 규제했다
event_translation.description: 증권 거래위원회는 주식 시장을 규제하고 투자자를 사기 행위로부터 보호하기 위해 설립되었다. 이는 1929년 주식 시장 붕괴 이후 금융 시스템에 대한 신뢰를 회복하는 중요한 단계였다.

event_translation.name: FCC가 전화, 전보 및 무선 통신의 연방 규제를 통합했다
event_translation.description: FCC의 통신 기술 연방 규제 통합은 감독을 간소화하고 대중을 위한 공정하고 효율적인 통신 서비스를 보장하기 위한 것이었다. 이는 미국 통신 인프라의 현대화에 있어서 중요한 발전이었다.

event_translation.name: 토양 보전 및 농가 배정법이 토양 보전 작물을 심은 농부들에게 보상을 지불했다
event_translation.description: 토양 보전 및 농가 배정법은 토양 침식에 대처하고 지속 가능한 농업 관행을 촉진하기 위해 토양 보전 작물을 심은 농부들에게 금전적 인센티브를 제공하는 것을 목표로 했다. 이러한 노력은 대공황 기간 동안 농업 부문을 재기하는 데 중요했다.

event_translation.name: 비상 구호 배정금이 공공 사업 진행 행정부를 창설했다
event_translation.description: 비상 구호 배정금은 공공 사업 진행 행정부의 설립으로 이어졌는데, 이는 대공황 기간 동안 많은 사람들을 고용시켜 다양한 공공 사업을 수행하여 필요한 일자리와 인프라 개선을 제공했다.

event_translation.name: 농촌 전기화법
event_translation.description: 농촌 전기화법은 1935년 5월 20일에 통과되었으며, 주로 농장을 포함한 농촌 지역에 전기를 공급하여 생산성과 삶의 질을 크게 향상시키는 것을 목표로 했다.

event_translation.name: 국가 노동 관계법/바그너법
event_translation.description: 국가 노동 관계법인 바그너법으로도 알려진 국가 노동 관계법은 1935년 7월 22일에 제정되어 노동자의 권리를 보호하고 공정한 노동 관행과 단체교섭을 보장하기 위해 국가 노동 관계위원회를 설립했다.

event_translation.name: 이주민 정착 행정청
event_translation.description: 이주민 정착 행정청은 1935년 4월 30일에 설립되어 대공황 시기에 농부들의 생활 조건과 농업 관행을 개선하기 위해 훈련과 대출을 제공했다.

event_translation.name: 우울증 재개
event_translation.description: 1937년 5월 26일, 경제는 다시 수축하기 시작하여 대공황의 재개를 알렸다.

event_translation.name: 일본이 펄하버를 공격한 사건
event_translation.description: 1941년 12월 7일, 일본은 하와이의 펄하버 해군기지에 서프라이즈 군사 공격을 발동하여 미국이 제2차 세계대전에 참전하게 되었다.

event_translation.name: 다우가 382.74로 폐장한 사건
event_translation.description: 1954년 11월 23일, 다우존스 산업평균지수는 382.74로 폐장하여 1929년 9월 3일에 세운 이전 기록을 뛰어넘었으며, 제2차 세계대전 이후의 경제 성장과 회복을 반영하고 있다.

event_translation.name: 스무트-할리 관세법
event_translation.description: 농업 및 제조업품에 관세를 인상시켜 외국의 보복을 일으키고 대공황을 악화시킨 스무트-할리 관세법.

event_translation.name: 국가 국가 국가 국가
event_translation.description: 허버트 후버 대통령이 '별들의 피아노'를 미국의 국가 애창곡으로 지정하는 법률에 서명함.

event_translation.name: 스콧스보로 소년들 사건
event_translation.description: '스콧스보로 소년들'이라 불리는 아프리카계 미국인 9명이 강간 혐의로 기소되어 아프리카계 미국인이 배심원으로 참여할 권리를 확립한 사례로 이어지는 사건.

event_translation.name: 재건 금융 공사 설립
event_translation.description: 대공황 기간 동안 경제를 안정화하기 위해 은행, 철도 및 보험회사에 대출을 제공하기 위해 재건 금융 공사가 설립됨.

event_translation.name: 린드버그 유괴 사건
event_translation.description: 비행사 찰스 린드버그의 아들이 유괴되어 고위험하고 비극적인 형사 사건으로 이어짐.

event_translation.name: 프랭클린 루즈벨트의 '뉴딜' 약속
event_translation.description: 민주당 대통령 후보 프랭클린 루즈벨트가 미국 역사와 대공황 시대의 중요한 순간을 표시하는 '뉴딜'을 미국인들에게 약속함.

event_translation.name: 보너스 군대의 워싱턴 철수
event_translation.description: 허버트 후버 대통령이 1945년에 예정된 보너스를 조기 지급을 요구하며 워싱턴에 2개월 동안 캠핑한 1만 5천 명의 제1차 세계대전 참전 군인들을 제거하기 위해 군대에 명령을 내린 사건. 참전 군인들은 강제로 캠프에서 내쫓기며 당국과의 격렬한 충돌을 일으켰다.

event_translation.name: 아돌프 히틀러의 독일 총리 임명
event_translation.description: 독일 나치당 지도자인 아돌프 히틀러가 총리로 임명되어 독일 정치의 중요한 전환점을 마킹하고 전체주의 체제의 수립을 이끌어내는 사건.

event_translation.name: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트 대통령 취임 및 뉴딜 캠페인 시작
event_translation.description: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트가 대통령으로 취임하고 대공황의 경제적 도전에 대처하기 위한 일련의 프로그램과 개혁을 시작하는 뉴딜 캠페인을 시작한 사건. 취임 연설에서 그는 '우리가 두려워해야 할 유일한 것은 두려움 그 자체뿐이다.'라는 상징적인 문구를 전달했다.

event_translation.name: 금지법 폐지
event_translation.description: 주류의 생산, 수입 및 판매를 금지했던 금지법이 폐지되어 미국의 13년간의 금지 시대를 종식시키는 사건. 이 사건은 사회적, 법적 정책에서의 중요한 변화를 나타내는 사건이었다.

event_translation.name: Dr. Francis Townsend의 연방 기금 연금 제안
event_translation.description: 퇴직한 치과의사인 Dr. Francis Townsend는 노인들을 지원하기 위해 연방 기금 연금을 설립하고자 하며, 대공황 시기의 노인들이 직면한 경제적 어려움에 대처하고자 합니다.

event_translation.name: John Dillinger가 FBI에 의해 총에 맞고 사망
event_translation.description: 악명 높은 은행 강도이자 공공의 적 1호인 John Dillinger가 시카고의 영화관을 나오는 도중 FBI에 의해 치명적으로 총에 맞아 사망하며, 대공황 시대 조직 범죄에 대한 정의 추구에서 중요한 사건으로 기록됩니다.

event_translation.name: Nuremberg Laws가 독일 유대인에게 시민권을 박탈하고 비유대인과의 혼인을 금지
