1.name: Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act passage
1.description: 스무트-할리 관세법이 통과되었을 때, 농산물 거래의 붕괴를 통해 주로 세계 경제를 약화시키고 농부들에게 대출을 많이 한 은행들을 압박했다. 이는 제조업품의 무역을 더욱 감소시켜 해고와 기업 이익 감소로 이어져 경제를 약화시켰다.

2.name: 1930 German federal election
2.description: 1930년 독일 연방 선거는 나치당과 공산당이 큰 성과를 거두어 라이히스타그에서 두 번째로 큰 정당이 되었다. 재임 중인 민주주의 바이마르 연립을 이루는 정당들은 참혹한 패배를 입었다.

3.name: Creditanstalt insolvency
3.description: 크레딧안스톨트는 오스트리아의 주요 은행으로 다양한 산업에 주요 지분을 가졌으나, 다른 세 은행의 파산으로 인한 부채를 강제로 떠안아 파산하게 되었고, 중앙 유럽 전역에 은행 파산의 연쇄 효과를 일으켰다. 크레딧안스톨트의 붕괴로 프랑스 은행, 벨기에 국립은행, 네덜란드 은행, 스위스 국립은행은 그들의 금 보유액을 위해 미국 달러를 달려들기 시작했고, 이로 인해 연방준비제도는 금 기준을 유지하기 위해 이자율을 1.5%에서 3.5%로 인상해야 했으며, 결과적으로 미국 내 은행 파산의 두 번째 라운드와 함께 불황을 더욱 심화시켰다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1931 May–June: Second major round of U.S. bank failures and worsening economic situation contributes to permanent change in people's expectation of the economy. This run was centered on bank in Chicago, which suffered from real estate loan defaults. Of the 193 state-chartered banks in the Chicago area in 1929, only 35 would survive to the end of 1933.[7] Chicago area banks engaged heavily in real estate lending between 1923 and 1929, and banks that had greater exposure to the real estate bust were very likely to fail. The deflationary spiral that began earlier in the year rapidly and severely intensifies

1931 June–July: German banking crisis. The Reichsbank loses 840 million marks in less than 3 weeks as investors pull out short-term deposits. Germany's second largest bank, Danatbank, becomes insolvent on July 13. Two day bank holiday is declared. Industry suffers a catastrophic collapse. The Hoover Moratorium is issued June 20, suspending reparation payments from Germany to stabilize the country. Although private banks in New York City and the Bank of England begin emergency lending to Germany, the banking crisis spills over into Hungary and Romania, and the collapse of the economy paves the way for Adolf Hitler's rise in the July 1932 and March 1933 German federal elections. The contagion also puts increasing pressure on the United Kingdom.August - Deepening deficits and demands for a balanced budget lead to Ramsay MacDonald's Labour government raising taxes by £24 million and cutting spending by £96 million, most controversial was the 20% cut to unemployment benefits (a sum of £64 million). The U.K.'s public debt at the time was 180% of GDP, mostly left over from the expenses of World War I. Public outrage would lead to the Labour Party being virtually destroyed in the October 1931 election.

1931 September 21: Britain leaves the gold standard, and the pound sterling depreciates by 25%. Despite warning of disaster, the departure proves beneficial to the British economy, as exports become more competitive. Additionally, the Bank of England was now free to engage in money creation, and reduced interest rates from 6.00% to 2.00%. Norway and Sweden follow on the 27th, Denmark on the 29th, and Finland on October 12. All four would later join the Sterling Area in 1933 by pegging their currencies to the British Pound. The Nordic countries were, like the United Kingdom, also able to switch to an inflationary monetary policy, allowing economic growth to return and unemployment to fall from 1931 onwards, much earlier than other countries who still clung to the gold standard.[8]

1931 October 27: the United Kingdom General election, 1931 takes place, destroying the Labour Party and delivering a landslide victory to the Conservative Party.

1931 September - October: Substantial amount of dollar assets (primarily Federal Reserve Notes) are converted to gold in the US by European central banks seeking to cover losses from the panic that had been sweeping Europe since the collapse of CreditAnstalt. In response, the Federal Reserve increases the federal funds rate from 1.50% to 3.50% to stabilize the dollar, but this only worsens the Depression as banks are further strained. The New York Federal Reserve Bank had loaned $150 million in gold (some 240 tons) to European central banks, and the wisdom of this was questioned as European countries rapidly abandoned the gold standard. As deflation intensified, real interest rates were magnified and rewarded those who held onto money, thus contributing to the deflationary spiral.

1.name: Second major round of U.S. bank failures
1.description: The worsening economic situation and U.S. bank failures in May 1931 contributed to a permanent change in people's expectations of the economy. The run was centered on a bank in Chicago, which suffered from real estate loan defaults. This event further intensified the deflationary spiral that began earlier in the year.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: German banking crisis
2.description: In June 1931, the German banking crisis led to catastrophic collapse in the industry. The Hoover Moratorium was issued to stabilize the country, and the crisis had far-reaching effects, including contributing to Adolf Hitler's rise in the German federal elections.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Ramsay MacDonald's Labour government budget cuts
3.description: In August 1931, deepening deficits and demands for a balanced budget led to Ramsay MacDonald's Labour government raising taxes and cutting spending, including a controversial 20% cut to unemployment benefits. These measures led to public outrage and the virtual destruction of the Labour Party in the October 1931 election.
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: Britain leaves the gold standard
4.description: On September 21, 1931, Britain left the gold standard, leading to a 25% depreciation of the pound sterling. Despite warnings of disaster, the departure proved beneficial to the British economy, as exports became more competitive. This event also allowed the Bank of England to engage in money creation and reduce interest rates, leading to economic growth and reduced unemployment.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: United Kingdom General election, 1931
5.description: On October 27, 1931, the United Kingdom General election took place, destroying the Labour Party and delivering a landslide victory to the Conservative Party.
5.subject: Great Depression

6.name: Conversion of dollar assets to gold in the US
6.description: In September-October 1931, a substantial amount of dollar assets were converted to gold in the US by European central banks seeking to cover losses from the panic sweeping Europe. This led to the Federal Reserve increasing the federal funds rate to stabilize the dollar, further worsening the Depression as banks were strained.
6.subject: Great Depression

1.name: 브리튼이 황금 표준을 떠나는 것
1.description: 1931년 9월 21일, 브리튼은 황금 표준을 떠나 25%의 파운드 스털링 가치 하락을 야기했다. 재앙을 예고했음에도 불구하고, 이탈은 영국 경제에 이로웠다. 수출이 더 경쟁력을 갖게 되었다. 또한 이 사건으로 잉글랜드 은행은 화폐 창조에 참여하고 이자율을 낮출 수 있었으며, 이는 경제 성장과 실업률 감소로 이어졌다.

2.name: 영국 총선, 1931년
2.description: 1931년 10월 27일, 영국 총선이 열려 노동당을 파멸시키고 보수당에 압도적인 승리를 안겼다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1932Year:Unemployment rises to 23%, GDP growth is -13%, annual inflation rate is -11%, 1,700 banks fail. US nominal GDP falls to $60 billion. Over 13 million in the U.S. are unemployed and 3.5 million in the U.K.January 22 - the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is created to lend $2 billion to troubled financial institutions that were not part of the Federal Reserve System that were solvent in the long-run. By 1941, the RFC would lend out some $9.5 billion to banks, railroads, and mortgage associations, as well as state and local governments.

1932 April - June: Federal Reserve conducts open market transactions, increasing the money supply by $1 billion.Summer 1932: Majority of foreign trade restrictions take effect, from Smoot-Hawley in the United States and Imperial Preference in the British Empire. The Import Duties Act 1932 passed in the United Kingdom imposes an initial tariff of 10% on most imports, but this rate is quickly raised to a range of rates from 15% to 33% shortly after the Act is passed.June 6 - The Revenue Act of 1932 is signed into law, raising taxes on personal income, corporate income, and sales taxes on various goods.

1932 July: U.S. government discontinues open market operations.

1932 July 8: The Dow Jones Industrial Index bottoms out at 41.22, the lowest level recorded in the 20th century and representing an 89% loss from its peak in September 1929.

1932 July 31: The German federal election, July 1932 is held, and the Nazi Party, led by Adolf Hitler, becomes the largest party in the Reichstag (but lacks a majority). For the first time, the combined strength of the Communists and Nazis means that there is an anti-democratic majority in Germany.

1932 November 6: The German federal election, November 1932, the last free and fair all-German election until 1990, is held. A minor setback for the Nazi Party, a campaign of mass violence and intimidation would begin in the run up to the next election in March 1933. Nonetheless, the anti-democratic majority between the Communists and Nazis is narrowly maintained. Hitler is later appointed Chancellor of Germany by President Paul von Hindenburg, and would use the Reichstag fire as a pretext to declare a state of emergency in Germany expanding his powers.

1932 November 8: 1932 United States elections: Franklin D. Roosevelt elected 32nd President of the United States in a landslide, the Democratic Party wins massive majorities in both chambers of Congress.

1.description: The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is created to lend $2 billion to troubled financial institutions that were not part of the Federal Reserve System that were solvent in the long-run. By 1941, the RFC would lend out some $9.5 billion to banks, railroads, and mortgage associations, as well as state and local governments.

Nonetheless, the anti-democratic majority between the Communists and Nazis is narrowly maintained.

1.name: 재건 금융 기구 창설
1.description: 재건 금융 기구는 연방준비제도의 일부가 아니었지만 장기적으로 지속 가능한 곤경에 처한 금융 기관들에게 20억 달러를 대출하기 위해 창설되었다. 1941년까지 RFC는 은행, 철도, 주택 협회뿐만 아니라 주지방 정부에도 95억 달러 가량을 대출했다.

2.name: 1932년 세입법 통과
2.description: 1932년 세입법이 공포되어 개인소득세, 법인소득세 및 다양한 상품의 판매세를 인상시켰다.

3.name: 다우존스 산업지수 최저점 도달
3.description: 다우존스 산업지수가 41.22로 역사상 최저치를 기록하며 1929년 9월의 최고치 대비 89%의 하락을 나타내었다.

4.name: 1932년 7월 독일 연방 선거
4.description: 아돌프 히틀러가 이끄는 나치당이 라이히스타그에서 최대 정당이 되었지만 다수를 차지하지는 못했다. 공산당과 나치당의 연합 강도로 인해 처음으로 독일에 반민주주의적 다수가 생겼다.

5.name: 1932년 11월 독일 연방 선거
5.description: 1990년까지 이어진 마지막 자유롭고 공정한 독일 전체 선거가 열렸다. 나치당에 소소한 저항이 있었지만, 1933년 3월 다음 선거를 앞두고 대규모 폭력과 위협 캠페인이 시작되었다. 그럼에도 불구하고 공산당과 나치당 사이의 반민주주의적 다수는 가깝게 유지되었다.

6.name: 1932년 미국 선거
6.description: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트가 민주당 후보로 대통령에 32대로 당선되었고, 민주당은 의회 양원에서 대규모 다수를 획득했다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input: 1933Year:The inflation rate turns positive, at 1% annually. Quarterly GDP growth turns positive by summer, but overall annual rate is -1.3% growth. Unemployment peaks at 25%. 2 million are homeless. Industrial production is half of what it was in 1929. US nominal GDP bottoms out at $57 billion (down from $105 billion in 1929)February 14: Michigan becomes the first state in the U.S. to declare an indefinite bank holiday, in an attempt to stem the impending collapse of First National Bank of Detroit and the Guardian National Bank of Commerce, the two largest banks in Detroit. First National and Guardian National were threatened with failure if the Ford Motor Company made good on its desire to withdraw all of its deposits in the two banks; Ford needed the cash to cover its $75 million loss in 1932. At this time, over 80% of Detroit's manufacturing capacity laid idle, and over 400,000 people were unemployed. Michigan's bank holiday set off a contagion of fear across the country, and by March 6 an additional 37 states would declare indefinite bank holidays.[9]

1.name: Michigan Declares Indefinite Bank Holiday
1.description: Michigan becomes the first state in the U.S. to declare an indefinite bank holiday, in an attempt to stem the impending collapse of First National Bank of Detroit and the Guardian National Bank of Commerce, the two largest banks in Detroit. This action was taken due to the threat of failure if the Ford Motor Company withdrew all of its deposits in the two banks, leading to widespread unemployment and economic instability.
1.subject: Great Depression

This action was taken due to the threat of failure if the Ford Motor Company withdrew all of its deposits in the two banks, leading to widespread unemployment and economic instability.', 'language_code_id': 2, 'event_id': 757}]

1.name: 미시간 무기한 은행 휴일 선언
1.description: 미시간은 미국에서 첫 번째로 무기한 은행 휴일을 선언하여, 디트로이트의 두 대형 은행인 포드 자동차 회사가 두 은행에 예금을 모두 철수할 경우 파산 위기를 막기 위해 이 조치가 취해졌다. 이로 인해 대규모 실업과 경제 불안이 초래될 것을 우려하여 이 조치가 취해졌다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input: 1933 March 4: Franklin D. Roosevelt is inaugurated as President.March 5 - The German federal election, March 1933 is held. The Nazi Party would win a narrow majority of seats, though only in coalition with the German National People's Party (DNVP). Though this would be the last free election before World War II, it is not considered to be a fair election, as the Nazi Party's paramilitary organizations waged a campaign of violence, censorship, intimidation, and harassment against all parties that opposed them with state support. Surveillance of voting was conducted on the day of the election itself.March 6 - Executive Order 2009 suspends all banking activity for one week, in response to renewed stress on major New York City banks that threatened another round of bank failures and further deepening of the Depression.[10] By this time, 38 states had declared bank holidays.March 9- The Emergency Banking Act was enacted, which enabled a restructuring of the banking system. Over 4,000 banks with $3.6 billion in deposits that were deemed irreparably insolvent were closed forever, but by March 15, banks controlling some 90% of the nation's banking activities were back in business. By the end of March, over $1.1 billion in hoarded cash was deposited into the banking system.[11] These new deposits saved cash-starved banks and helped restart the money creation process after years of credit contraction. The Act also created the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), which insured deposits up to $2,500 and helped restore confidence in the banking system.March 20 - The controversial Economy Act of 1933 is signed into law, slashing $243 million in government salaries and pensions, and veterans' benefits. Despite the economic crisis, supermajorities of American economists, policymakers, and the general public believed that the federal government needed to balance the budget and avoid deficit spending, to avoid putting further strain on the bond market which would negatively affect government borrowing costs, banks, corporations, and foreign investors. From 1929 to 1933, the total debt owed by the U.S. government rose from $16.9 billion to over $23 billion. This "Economy" Act was designed to reduce government outlays and assuage fears about government debt and deficits.March 31 - The Civilian Conservation Corps, a public works relief program, is created. It would last until 1942 and is an icon of the New Deal programs.April 5 - Executive Order 6102 of President Franklin D. Roosevelt issued, forbidding hoarding of gold coin, bullion, and certificates, effective from May 1, 1933May 12 - the Agricultural Adjustment Act is enacted, designed to boost agricultural prices by reducing surpluses.May 27 - the Securities Act of 1933 is enacted, requiring the registration of all sales and purchases of financial securities, as well as the disclosure of critical financial information about the firms involved. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission was established the following year, which helped combat insider trading and reducing transaction risk.July - Federal Reserve industrial production index rebounds to 85.5, a 57% increase over the 54.3 recorded in March 1933November 8 - the Civil Works Administration is created, which would employ over 4 million people and distribute over $400 million in funds for work programs through its end on March 31, 1934, when it would be replaced by the more permanent Works Progress AdministrationDecember 5 - Prohibition is repealed at the national level. 18 states continue with state-level prohibition. The end of Prohibition hurts organized crime, allows legal employment in alcoholic drink production, and increases state tax revenues.

1.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt's Inauguration
1.description: Franklin D. Roosevelt is inaugurated as the 32nd President of the United States, marking the beginning of his presidency during the Great Depression.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: German Federal Election, March 1933
2.description: The Nazi Party wins a narrow majority of seats in the German federal election, marking a significant step towards their consolidation of power in Germany.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Executive Order 2009 Suspends Banking Activity
3.description: Executive Order 2009 suspends all banking activity for one week in response to renewed stress on major New York City banks, aiming to prevent further deepening of the Depression.
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: Enactment of the Emergency Banking Act
4.description: The Emergency Banking Act is enacted, enabling the restructuring of the banking system and the creation of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) to restore confidence in the banking system during the Great Depression.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: Signing of the Economy Act of 1933
5.description: The controversial Economy Act of 1933 is signed into law, aiming to reduce government outlays and balance the budget during the economic crisis of the Great Depression.
5.subject: Great Depression

6.name: Creation of the Civilian Conservation Corps
6.description: The Civilian Conservation Corps, a public works relief program, is created as part of the New Deal programs to provide employment and conservation efforts during the Great Depression.
6.subject: Great Depression

7.name: Executive Order 6102 Forbids Hoarding of Gold
7.description: President Franklin D. Roosevelt issues Executive Order 6102, forbidding the hoarding of gold coin, bullion, and certificates, as a measure to stabilize the economy during the Great Depression.
7.subject: Great Depression

8.name: Enactment of the Agricultural Adjustment Act
8.description: The Agricultural Adjustment Act is enacted, aiming to boost agricultural prices by reducing surpluses during the Great Depression.
8.subject: Great Depression

9.name: Enactment of the Securities Act of 1933
9.description: The Securities Act of 1933 is enacted, requiring the registration of all sales and purchases of financial securities, aiming to combat insider trading and reduce transaction risk during the Great Depression.
9.subject: Great Depression

10.name: Federal Reserve Industrial Production Index Rebounds
10.description: The Federal Reserve industrial production index rebounds during July, indicating a significant increase in industrial output and economic recovery during the Great Depression.
10.subject: Great Depression

11.name: Creation of the Civil Works Administration
11.description: The Civil Works Administration is created, employing over 4 million people and distributing funds for work programs during the Great Depression.
11.subject: Great Depression

12.name: Repeal of Prohibition at the National Level
12.description: Prohibition is repealed at the national level, marking the end of the era of alcohol prohibition in the United States and its impact on organized crime, employment, and state tax revenues.
12.subject: Great Depression

1.name: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트의 취임식
1.description: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트가 미국의 32번째 대통령으로 취임되어 대공황 시기의 대통령직을 시작함을 나타냄.

2.name: 1933년 3월 독일 연방 선거
2.description: 나치당이 독일 연방 선거에서 좁은 다수를 획득하여 독일에서 권력을 확고히 하는 중요한 단계를 나타냄.

3.name: 행정명령 2009번이 은행 활동 중단
3.description: 행정명령 2009번이 뉴욕시 주요 은행들에 대한 재압력에 대응하여 한 주간 모든 은행 활동을 중단시키고 대공황의 심화를 막으려 함.

4.name: 긴급 은행법 시행
4.description: 긴급 은행법이 시행되어 은행 시스템을 재구성하고 연방 예금 보험공사(FDIC)를 설립하여 대공황 시기의 은행 시스템에 대한 신뢰를 회복시키려 함.

5.name: 1933년 경제법 서명
5.description: 논란이 많은 1933년 경제법이 서명되어 경제 위기 시기에 정부 지출을 줄이고 예산을 균형있게 하려 함.

6.name: 시민 보전부 창설
6.description: 대공황 시기의 고용과 보전 노력을 위해 뉴딜 프로그램의 일환으로 시민 보전부가 창설됨.

7.name: 행정명령 6102번이 금 보유 금지
7.description: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트 대통령이 행정명령 6102번을 발표하여 금화, 금괴, 증권의 보유를 금지하여 대공황 시기의 경제 안정화를 위한 조치로 채택됨.

8.name: 농업 조정법 시행
8.description: 농업 조정법이 시행되어 대공황 시기의 농산물 과잉을 줄이고 농산물 가격을 높이려 함.

9.name: 1933년 증권법 시행
9.description: 증권법이 시행되어 모든 금융 증권의 매매를 등록하도록 하여 대공황 시기의 내부자거래를 막고 거래 위험을 줄이려 함.

10.name: 시민 공사 행정부 창설
10.description: 시민 공사 행정부가 창설되어 400만 명 이상의 사람들을 고용하고 대공황 시기의 일자리 프로그램에 자금을 배정함.

11.name: 국가적으로 금지법 폐지
11.description: 국가적으로 금지법이 폐지되어 미국의 술 금지 시대가 종료되고 조직 범죄, 고용, 주세 수입에 미치는 영향이 나타남.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1929:1929 stock market crashThe crowds on Wall Street, New York, after the stock exchange crashed. PHOTO BY FOX PHOTOS/GETTY IMAGES

1929 March 4: Herbert Hoover became president. His laissez-faire economic policies did little to stop the Depression.He believed a free-market economy would allow the forces of capitalism to fix any economic downturn. As a result, he lowered the top income tax rate from 25% to 24%.2August: The economic activity from the Roaring Twenties reached its peak. After that, it started to contract. It was the true start of the Great Depression.That same month, the Federal Reserve raised the discount rate from 5% to 6% to prevent inflation and defend the gold standard.3

1929 Sept. 3: Dow reached a closing record of 381.7. The stock market would not return to its pre-crash high for the next 25 years.

1929 Oct. 24: Black Thursday kicked off the stock market crash of 1929. Stock prices immediately fell 11%.Wall Street bankers bought stocks, so only 2% was lost by the time the market closed.Oct. 25-26: Stocks gained 1% on Friday but lost 1% during a half-day of trading on Saturday.

1929 Oct. 28: On Black Monday, stocks prices fell 13%.

1.name: Stock Market Crash of 1929
1.description: The stock market crash of 1929, also known as Black Thursday, kicked off with stock prices immediately falling 11%. Although Wall Street bankers bought stocks, only 2% was lost by the time the market closed. The following days saw further fluctuations in stock prices.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: Herbert Hoover Became President
2.description: Herbert Hoover became president on March 4, 1929. His laissez-faire economic policies did little to stop the Great Depression. He believed in a free-market economy and lowered the top income tax rate from 25% to 24%.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Peak of Roaring Twenties Economic Activity
3.description: In August 1929, the economic activity from the Roaring Twenties reached its peak and started to contract, marking the true start of the Great Depression. The Federal Reserve also raised the discount rate from 5% to 6% to prevent inflation and defend the gold standard.
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: Dow Reached Closing Record of 381.7
4.description: On September 3, 1929, the Dow reached a closing record of 381.7. The stock market would not return to its pre-crash high for the next 25 years.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: Black Monday
5.description: On October 28, 1929, stocks prices fell 13%, marking the infamous Black Monday during the stock market crash of 1929.
5.subject: Great Depression

1.name: 1929년 주식 시장 대란
1.description: 1929년 주식 시장 대란은 블랙 목요일로도 알려져 있으며 주식 가격이 즉시 11% 하락하면서 시작되었다. 월가 은행가들이 주식을 사들였지만 시장이 마감될 때까지 2%밖에 손실이 나지 않았다. 이어진 며칠 동안 주식 가격은 계속 변동하였다.

2.name: 허버트 후버 대통령 취임
2.description: 허버트 후버는 1929년 3월 4일에 대통령으로 취임하였다. 그의 자유주의적 경제 정책은 대공황을 막는 데 별다른 성과를 내지 못했다. 그는 자유 시장 경제를 신봉하고 상위 소득세율을 25%에서 24%로 낮추었다.

3.name: 다우 지수 381.7 포인트로 최고치 마감
3.description: 1929년 9월 3일, 다우 지수는 381.7 포인트로 최고치를 기록하였다. 주식 시장은 다음 25년 동안 이전 대란 이전 수준으로 돌아가지 않았다.

4.name: 블랙 먼데이
4.description: 1929년 10월 28일, 주가가 13% 하락하여 악명 높은 블랙 먼데이를 기록하였다. 이는 1929년 주식 시장 대란 중 가장 유명한 사건 중 하나이다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1929 Oct. 29: On Black Tuesday, the market lost another 12% as a record 16 million shares were traded. When banks intervened this time, they worsened the panic.

1929 Nov. 23: The stock market hit bottom and began trading sideways.December: The unemployment rate was still just 3.2%. Since unemployment is a lagging indicator, it hadn't started to worsen yet.There were more than 650 bank failures in 1929, part of a trend of such failures throughout the 1920s. As banks failed, it reduced the money supply because there was less credit available. That meant each dollar was worth more.As the value of the dollar rose, prices fell, which reduced revenue for businesses. It also meant that debt cost more for lenders to pay back.This created a ripple effect of personal and business bankruptcies.4

1930:Soup kitchenDolly Gann (L), sister of U.S. vice president Charles Curtis, helps serve meals to the hungry at a Salvation Army soup kitchen on December 27, 1930. PHOTO: AMERICAN STOCK/GETTY IMAGES

1.name: Black Tuesday Market Crash
1.description: On Black Tuesday, the market lost another 12% as a record 16 million shares were traded. Banks intervention worsened the panic, leading to a significant economic downturn.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: Stock Market Bottom
2.description: The stock market hit bottom and began trading sideways, marking a critical point in the economic downturn of the Great Depression.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Unemployment Rate at 3.2%
3.description: In December, the unemployment rate was still just 3.2%, indicating the early stage of the economic crisis during the Great Depression.
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: Bank Failures and Reduced Money Supply
4.description: More than 650 bank failures occurred in 1929, contributing to the reduction of the money supply and the subsequent economic challenges during the Great Depression.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: Ripple Effect of Bankruptcies
5.description: The series of bank failures and reduced money supply led to a ripple effect of personal and business bankruptcies, deepening the economic crisis during the Great Depression.
5.subject: Great Depression

6.name: Soup Kitchen
6.description: Dolly Gann, sister of U.S. vice president Charles Curtis, helps serve meals to the hungry at a Salvation Army soup kitchen on December 27, 1930, reflecting the widespread impact of the Great Depression on the American society.
6.subject: Great Depression

1.name: 블랙 투즈데이 마켓 크래시
1.description: 블랙 투즈데이에 시장은 또 다른 12%를 잃었고, 사상 최대 1600만 주가 거래되었다. 은행의 개입으로 인해 공포가 더욱 악화되었고, 중대한 경제 침체로 이어졌다.

2.name: 주식 시장 바닥
2.description: 주식 시장은 바닥을 치고 측면으로 거래를 시작하여 대공황의 중요한 지점을 표시했다.

3.name: 수프 주방
3.description: 미국 부통령 찰스 커티스의 자매 돌리 갠은 1930년 12월 27일 새벽부터 미국 사회에 대대적인 영향을 미친 대공황을 반영하여 구제군 수프 주방에서 주방을 도와주었다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1930 June 17: Hoover signed the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act, which raised taxes on 900 imports.5 It originally was supposed to help farmers but ended up imposing tariffs on hundreds of other products.Other countries retaliated, setting off a trade war. As a result, international trade began to collapse.A drought hit 23 states from the Mississippi River to the mid-Atlantic region. It was the first of what later was called the Dust Bowl drought, the worst in 300 years.As crops failed, farmers could not produce enough to eat. At first, Hoover asked the American Red Cross to help. As the crisis worsened, Congress appropriated $65 million for seed, feed, and food boxes.

1930 July 21: Hoover created the Department of Veterans Affairs.6

1.name: Signing of the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act
1.description: In 1930, President Hoover signed the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act, which raised taxes on 900 imports. Initially intended to assist farmers, it resulted in imposing tariffs on numerous other products, leading to a trade war and the collapse of international trade.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: Dust Bowl drought begins
2.description: In 1930, a drought hit 23 states from the Mississippi River to the mid-Atlantic region, marking the beginning of the Dust Bowl drought, which was later considered the worst in 300 years. The drought led to crop failures and food shortages for farmers.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Creation of the Department of Veterans Affairs
3.description: On July 21, 1930, President Hoover created the Department of Veterans Affairs, aiming to provide support and services to American veterans. This was a significant step in addressing the needs of veterans following World War I.
3.subject: Great Depression

This was a significant step in addressing the needs of veterans following World War I.', 'language_code_id': 2, 'event_id': 777}]

1.name: Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act Signing
1.description: 1930년, 후버 대통령이 Smoot-Hawley 관세법을 서명했는데, 이 법은 900가지 물품에 대한 세금을 인상시켰다. 초기에는 농부들을 돕기 위해 의도되었으나, 결국은 다른 많은 제품에 관세를 부과하고 국제 무역의 붕괴로 이어지게 되었다.

2.name: Department of Veterans Affairs Creation
2.description: 1930년 7월 21일, 후버 대통령이 미국 전쟁 참전 군인들에게 지원과 서비스를 제공하기 위해 미국 전쟁 참전 군인처를 설립했다. 이것은 제1차 세계대전 이후의 군인들의 요구를 해결하는 데 중요한 한 걸음이었다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1930 Nov. 7: The Bank of Tennessee failed. This led to the failures of affiliate banks in the next few days. Although the economy was improving, weaknesses in the banking system pulled it back down.Only one-third of the nation's 24,000 banks belonged to the Federal Reserve banking system. Non-members did not have enough access to reserves to fend off bank runs.As bank failures grew, depositors rushed to banks to pull out their savings.7 Banks held only 10% of all deposits, so they could lend out the rest. A bank run would quickly put it out of business.In the fall of 1930, bank runs spread throughout the Southeastern United States. By the end of the year, more than 1,300 banks had failed.4

1930 Dec. 11: The Bank of the United States failed.8 It was the fourth-largest bank in the nation, and the largest bank failure in history at that time.Worried about budget deficits, Hoover returned the top income tax rate to 25%. The economy shrank 8.5%.The unemployment rate rose to 8.7%. Deflation set in as prices fell 6.4%.

1.name: Bank of Tennessee Failure
1.description: The failure of the Bank of Tennessee on November 7, 1930, led to the collapse of affiliate banks in the following days, contributing to the worsening of the economy. The weaknesses in the banking system, with only one-third of the nation's banks being part of the Federal Reserve system, exacerbated the situation, leading to bank runs and widespread failures.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: Bank of the United States Failure
2.description: On December 11, 1930, the failure of the Bank of the United States, the fourth-largest bank in the nation at the time, marked the largest bank failure in history. This event further deepened the economic crisis, leading to significant budget deficits, an 8.5% contraction in the economy, and a rise in unemployment to 8.7%.
2.subject: Great Depression

This event further deepened the economic crisis, leading to significant budget deficits, an 8.5% contraction in the economy, and a rise in unemployment to 8.7%.', 'language_code_id': 2, 'event_id': 779}]

1.name: 테네시 은행 파산
1.description: 1930년 11월 7일 테네시 은행의 파산으로 이어진 계열 은행들의 붕괴는 이후 몇 일 동안 악화되는 경제 상황에 기여하여, 미국 은행 시스템의 취약점은 전국의 은행 중 3분의 1만 연방준비제도의 일원이었던 점이 상황을 악화시켜 은행 단체행동과 대규모 파산을 야기시켰다.

2.name: 미국 은행 파산
2.description: 1930년 12월 11일, 당시 미국에서 4번째로 큰 은행이었던 미국 은행의 파산은 역사상 최대 규모의 은행 파산을 나타내었다. 이 사건은 경제 위기를 더욱 심화시켜 중요한 예산 적자, 경제의 8.5% 축소, 그리고 8.7%의 실업률 상승으로 이어졌다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1931:soup lineA line of men wait outside a soup kitchen opened by mobster Al Capone, Chicago, Illinois, February 1931. PHOTO BY PHOTOQUEST/GETTY IMAGESFebruary: Food riots broke out in Minneapolis.The drought continued, hitting eight Southern states the worst. It was the worst drought in the 20th century for Arkansas.The economy shrank 6.4%. The unemployment rate rose to 15.9%. Prices fell another 9.3%.People began to suffer the worst effects of the Great Depression.

1932:January: Congress created the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to lend $2 billion to financial institutions to prevent further failures.9 In July, Congress authorized it to lend money to states for relief.February: The Fed purchased $1 billion in securities from banks as part of its open market operations. That added liquidity to cash-strapped banks.March: Economy bottomed after shrinking 27% since its peak in August 1929.

1932 June 6: Hoover signed the Revenue Act of 1932, which increased the top income tax rate to 63%. He wanted to reduce the federal deficit.Hoover believed this also would restore economic confidence. Instead, higher taxes worsened the depression.

1.name: Soup Kitchen Opened by Al Capone
1.description: In February 1931, mobster Al Capone opened a soup kitchen in Chicago, Illinois to provide food for the needy during the Great Depression.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: Food Riots in Minneapolis
2.description: Food riots broke out in Minneapolis in 1931 as a result of the worsening economic conditions and food shortages during the Great Depression.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Worst Drought in Arkansas
3.description: In 1931, Arkansas experienced the worst drought in the 20th century, exacerbating the economic hardships faced during the Great Depression.
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: Economic Contraction and Unemployment
4.description: In 1931, the economy shrank by 6.4% and the unemployment rate rose to 15.9%, reflecting the severe impact of the Great Depression on the economy and employment.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: Creation of Reconstruction Finance Corporation
5.description: In January 1932, Congress created the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to provide financial assistance and prevent further failures during the Great Depression.
5.subject: Great Depression

6.name: Economy Bottomed After Shrinking 27%
6.description: In March 1932, the economy reached its lowest point after shrinking by 27% since its peak in August 1929, marking a significant milestone in the Great Depression.
6.subject: Great Depression

7.name: Revenue Act of 1932
7.description: On June 6, 1932, President Hoover signed the Revenue Act of 1932, increasing the top income tax rate to 63% in an attempt to reduce the federal deficit, but it had a negative impact on the economy during the Great Depression.
7.subject: Great Depression

1.name: 1932년 수입법
1.description: 1932년 6월 6일 후버 대통령이 1932년 수입법에 서명하여 연방 적자를 줄이려고 최상위 소득세율을 63%로 인상했지만 대공황 기간에 경제에 부정적인 영향을 미쳤다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1932 July 8: Dow bottomed at 41.22. That was a 90% slide from its September 1929 pre-crash high.September: Bank failures slowed, construction contracts increased 30%, and department store sales rose 8%.Fourteen dust storms hit the Midwest. The economy shrank 12.9%, unemployment rose to 23.6%, and prices fell 10.3%.

1933:

1933 March 9: Franklin Delano Roosevelt launched the New Deal with the Emergency Banking Act. It closed all U.S. banks to stop devastating failures.

1933 March 20: The Government Economy Act cut government spending to finance the New Deal.

1933 March 22: The Beer-Wine Revenue Act ended Prohibition and taxed alcohol sales to raise revenue.

1933 March 31: The Civilian Conservation Corps was launched to hire 3 million workers to maintain public lands.10

1.name: Dow Jones Industrial Average hits bottom at 41.22
1.description: On July 8, 1932, the Dow Jones Industrial Average hit a low of 41.22, marking a 90% decline from its pre-crash high in September 1929. This event symbolized the depth of the Great Depression's impact on the stock market.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: Economic indicators show signs of improvement
2.description: In September 1932, bank failures slowed, construction contracts increased by 30%, and department store sales rose by 8%. However, the Midwest was hit by fourteen dust storms, contributing to a 12.9% economic shrinkage, a 23.6% unemployment rate, and a 10.3% fall in prices.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt launches the New Deal with the Emergency Banking Act
3.description: On March 9, 1933, President Franklin D. Roosevelt initiated the New Deal with the Emergency Banking Act, which aimed to stabilize the banking system by temporarily closing all U.S. banks to prevent further failures during the Great Depression.
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: Government Economy Act reduces government spending for New Deal financing
4.description: The Government Economy Act, enacted on March 20, 1933, aimed to reduce government spending to finance the New Deal initiatives, reflecting the government's efforts to address the economic challenges of the Great Depression.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: Beer-Wine Revenue Act ends Prohibition and introduces alcohol sales tax
5.description: On March 22, 1933, the Beer-Wine Revenue Act was passed, ending Prohibition and introducing taxes on alcohol sales to generate revenue for the government during the Great Depression.
5.subject: Great Depression

6.name: Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) established to employ workers for public land maintenance
6.description: The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) was launched on March 31, 1933, as part of the New Deal to address unemployment by hiring 3 million workers for the maintenance of public lands, reflecting the government's efforts to stimulate the economy during the Great Depression.
6.subject: Great Depression

Roosevelt initiated the New Deal with the Emergency Banking Act, which aimed to stabilize the banking system by temporarily closing all U.S. banks to prevent further failures during the Great Depression.', 'language_code_id': 2, 'event_id': 782}, {'name': 'Government Economy Act reduces government spending for New Deal financing', 'description': "The Government Economy Act, enacted on March 20, 1933, aimed to reduce government spending to finance the New Deal initiatives, reflecting the government's efforts to address the economic challenges of the Great Depression.", 'language_code_id': 2, 'event_id': 783}, {'name': 'Beer-Wine Revenue Act ends Prohibition and introduces alcohol sales tax', 'description': 'On March 22, 1933, the Beer-Wine Revenue Act was passed, ending Prohibition and introducing taxes on alcohol sales to generate revenue for the government during the Great Depression.', 'language_code_id': 2, 'event_id': 784}, {'name': 'Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) established to employ workers for public land maintenance', 'description': "The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) was launched on March 31, 1933, as part of the New Deal to address unemployment by hiring 3 million workers for the maintenance of public lands, reflecting the government's efforts to stimulate the economy during the Great Depression.", 'language_code_id': 2, 'event_id': 785}]

1.name: 다우 존스 산업평균 지수가 41.22에서 최저점을 기록
1.description: 1932년 7월 8일, 다우 존스 산업평균 지수는 41.22로 하락하여 1929년 9월 주가 대 폭락 이전 수준에서 90% 하락을 나타내었다. 이 사건은 대공황이 주식 시장에 미친 영향의 심각성을 상징화했다.

2.name: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트가 긴급 은행법으로 뉴딜을 시작
2.description: 1933년 3월 9일, 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트 대통령은 긴급 은행법으로 뉴딜을 시작하였으며, 이 법은 대공황 기간 동안 미국의 모든 은행을 일시적으로 폐쇄하여 은행 시스템을 안정화하는 것을 목표로 하였다.

3.name: 정부 경제법이 뉴딜 자금 조달을 위해 정부 지출을 줄임
3.description: 1933년 3월 20일에 시행된 정부 경제법은 뉴딜 계획을 자금 조달하기 위해 정부 지출을 줄이는 것을 목표로 하였으며, 대공황 기간의 경제적 도전에 대한 정부의 노력을 반영하였다.

4.name: 맥주-와인 수입세법이 금지 종료 및 주류 판매세 도입
4.description: 1933년 3월 22일, 맥주-와인 수입세법이 통과되어 금지를 종료하고 대공황 기간 동안 정부의 수입을 위해 주류 판매에 세금을 도입하였다.

5.name: 시민 보전 군사 (CCC)가 공공 지역 유지보수를 위해 노동자를 고용
5.description: 시민 보전 군사 (CCC)는 1933년 3월 31일에 뉴딜의 일환으로 출범하여 300만 명의 노동자를 고용하여 공공 지역의 유지보수를 담당하였으며, 대공황 기간 동안 경제를 촉진하기 위한 정부의 노력을 반영하였다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input: 1933 April 19: FDR stopped a run on gold by abandoning the gold standard. He ordered everyone to exchange private gold for dollars.May: The Federal Emergency Relief Act created more federal jobs.11 The Agricultural Adjustment Act paid farmers to limit crops, thus raising prices.The Emergency Farm Mortgage Act provided loans to save farms from foreclosure.12 The Tennessee Valley Authority Act built power stations in the poorest area in the nation.The Securities Act required companies to educate investors when issuing stocks.13June: The government stopped repaying dollars with gold. The Home Owners Loan Corporation refinanced mortgages to prevent foreclosures.The Glass-Steagall Act separated investment banking from retail banking and created the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The National Industrial Recovery Act created the Public Works Administration, which added more jobs.14The National Recovery Administration outlawed child labor, established a minimum wage, and limited the workday to eight hours. It also allowed trade unions to bargain with employers.The Emergency Railroad Transportation Act coordinated the national railway systems.15

1.name: FDR Abandoned Gold Standard
1.description: On April 19, 1933, FDR stopped a run on gold by abandoning the gold standard and ordered the exchange of private gold for dollars.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: Federal Emergency Relief Act
2.description: In May 1933, the Federal Emergency Relief Act was passed to create more federal jobs to address the unemployment crisis during the Great Depression.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Agricultural Adjustment Act
3.description: On May 11, 1933, the Agricultural Adjustment Act was enacted to pay farmers to limit crops, thus raising prices, as a measure to combat the agricultural crisis during the Great Depression.
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: Emergency Farm Mortgage Act
4.description: The Emergency Farm Mortgage Act of May 12, 1933, provided loans to save farms from foreclosure during the Great Depression.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: Tennessee Valley Authority Act
5.description: On May 12, 1933, the Tennessee Valley Authority Act was passed to build power stations in the poorest area in the nation during the Great Depression.
5.subject: Great Depression

6.name: Securities Act
6.description: In May 1933, the Securities Act was passed to require companies to educate investors when issuing stocks, aiming to restore confidence in the stock market during the Great Depression.
6.subject: Great Depression

7.name: Government Stopped Repaying Dollars with Gold
7.description: In June 1933, the government stopped repaying dollars with gold, marking a significant shift in monetary policy during the Great Depression.
7.subject: Great Depression

8.name: Home Owners Loan Corporation Refinanced Mortgages
8.description: In June 1933, the Home Owners Loan Corporation was established to refinance mortgages and prevent foreclosures, providing relief to homeowners during the Great Depression.
8.subject: Great Depression

9.name: Glass-Steagall Act
9.description: In June 1933, the Glass-Steagall Act was passed to separate investment banking from retail banking and create the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp, aiming to stabilize the banking system during the Great Depression.
9.subject: Great Depression

10.name: National Industrial Recovery Act
10.description: In June 1933, the National Industrial Recovery Act was passed to create the Public Works Administration, which added more jobs, as a response to the unemployment crisis during the Great Depression.
10.subject: Great Depression

11.name: National Recovery Administration
11.description: On June 14, 1933, the National Recovery Administration was established to outlaw child labor, establish a minimum wage, limit the workday to eight hours, and allow trade unions to bargain with employers during the Great Depression.
11.subject: Great Depression

12.name: Emergency Railroad Transportation Act
12.description: On June 15, 1933, the Emergency Railroad Transportation Act was enacted to coordinate the national railway systems during the Great Depression.
12.subject: Great Depression

1.name: FDR의 금 표준 포기
1.description: 1933년 4월 19일, FDR은 금 표준을 포기하고 사립 금을 달러로 환전하도록 명령하여 금에 대한 동행을 멈추었다.

2.name: 농업 조정법
2.description: 1933년 5월 11일, 농업 조정법이 제정되어 농부들에게 작물을 제한하고 가격을 높이기 위해 농업 위기에 대응하는 조치로 농부들에게 보상을 지급하기로 되었다.

3.name: 긴급 농지 모기지법
3.description: 1933년 5월 12일, 대공황 기간 동안 판매를 막기 위해 농지를 구제하기 위해 대공황 농지 모기지법이 대출을 제공했다.

4.name: 테네시 강 계획법
4.description: 1933년 5월 12일, 미국에서 가장 가난한 지역에 발전소를 건설하기 위해 테네시 강 계획법이 통과되었다.

5.name: 국가 경제 회복 행정부
5.description: 1933년 6월 14일, 국가 경제 회복 행정부가 설립되어 대공황 기간 동안 아동 노동을 금지하고 최저 임금을 제정하고 일일 근로시간을 8시간으로 제한하고 노동조합이 사업주와 다툴 수 있도록 허용되었다.

6.name: 긴급 철도 운송법
6.description: 1933년 6월 15일, 국가 철도 시스템을 조정하기 위해 긴급 철도 운송법이 제정되었다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1933 Nov. 8: The Civil Works Administration created 4 million construction jobs.16Forty-eight dust storms pummeled Oklahoma and surrounding states.17 Farmers slaughtered 6 million pigs to reduce supply and boost prices.The public criticized the waste of food. FDR created the Federal Surplus Relief Corporation to use excess farm output to feed the poor.The economy shrank 1.3%. Unemployment rose to a record 24.9%. Prices rose 0.8%. The national debt was $23 billion.

1934:Depression soup line

1934 Jan. 30: The Gold Reserve Act prohibited private ownership of gold and doubled its price. The act changed gold price history.

1934 April 15: Black Sunday was the worst dust storm ever.18 FDR passed the Soil Conservation Act to teach farmers sustainable methods.

1.name: Creation of Civil Works Administration
1.description: The Civil Works Administration was created, providing 4 million construction jobs to combat unemployment during the Great Depression. This initiative aimed to stimulate the economy and address the widespread unemployment crisis.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: Dust Storms in Oklahoma and Surrounding States
2.description: Forty-eight dust storms pummeled Oklahoma and surrounding states, exacerbating the environmental and agricultural challenges faced during the Great Depression.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Slaughter of 6 Million Pigs
3.description: In an effort to reduce supply and boost prices, farmers slaughtered 6 million pigs during the Great Depression. This led to public criticism regarding the waste of food resources.
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: Creation of Federal Surplus Relief Corporation
4.description: FDR created the Federal Surplus Relief Corporation to utilize excess farm output to feed the poor, addressing the issue of food waste and scarcity during the Great Depression.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: Economic Contraction and Rising Unemployment
5.description: The economy shrank by 1.3% and unemployment rose to a record 24.9% during the Great Depression, reflecting the severe economic challenges faced by the nation.
5.subject: Great Depression

6.name: Depression Soup Line
6.description: The establishment of depression soup lines became a common sight during the Great Depression, providing basic sustenance to those in need amidst widespread poverty and food scarcity.
6.subject: Great Depression

7.name: Gold Reserve Act
7.description: The Gold Reserve Act was passed, prohibiting private ownership of gold and doubling its price, marking a significant shift in the regulation and value of gold during the Great Depression.
7.subject: Great Depression

8.name: Black Sunday Dust Storm
8.description: Black Sunday, the worst dust storm ever recorded, occurred during the Great Depression, prompting FDR to pass the Soil Conservation Act to address the environmental devastation and promote sustainable farming methods.
8.subject: Great Depression

1.name: 시민 공사 행정부의 창설
1.description: 시민 공사 행정부가 창설되어 대공황 시기 실업 문제 해결을 위해 400만 개의 건설 일자리를 제공했다. 이 개혁은 경제를 촉진하고 광범위한 실업 위기에 대처하기 위한 것이었다.

2.name: 금 보유법
2.description: 금 보유법이 통과되어 대공황 시기 금의 규제와 가치에 중대한 변화를 가져왔다. 이로써 금의 사유 소유가 금지되었고 가격은 두 배로 올랐다.

3.name: 검은 일요일 먼지 폭풍
3.description: 대공황 시기 중 가장 심각한 먼지 폭풍인 '검은 일요일'이 발생하여 FDR은 환경 파괴와 지속 가능한 농업 방법을 촉진하기 위해 토양 보전법을 통과시켰다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1934 June 27: The Federal Housing Administration provided federal mortgage insurance. The Securities and Exchange Commission regulated the stock market.The FCC consolidated all federal regulation of telephone, telegraph, and radio communications.The year recorded the hottest temperatures on record. There were 29 consecutive days with temperatures at or above 100 degrees.By the end of the year, droughts covered 75% of the country and 27 states. Almost 80% of the country recorded extremely dry conditions.The economy grew 10.8% in response to the New Deal Programs. Unemployment fell to 21.7%. Prices rose 1.5%. The debt rose to $27 billion.

1935:Farming in 1935Team of two work horses hitched to a wagon, farm house visible in the background, low-angle view, Beltsville, Maryland, 1935. From the New York Public Library. PHOTO BY SMITH COLLECTION/GADO/GETTY IMAGESThe Supreme Court declared the National Industrial Recovery Act unconstitutional. FDR launched more programs focused on the poor, the unemployed, and farmers.February 26: The Soil Conservation & Domestic Allotment Act paid farmers to plant soil-building crops.19

1935 April 8: The Emergency Relief Appropriation created the Works Progress Administration to hire 8.5 million people.2021

1.name: Federal Housing Administration provided federal mortgage insurance
1.description: The Federal Housing Administration provided federal mortgage insurance to help revive the housing market and provide affordable housing for Americans. This was a key component of the New Deal programs aimed at stimulating the economy and addressing the housing crisis during the Great Depression.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: Securities and Exchange Commission regulated the stock market
2.description: The Securities and Exchange Commission was established to regulate the stock market and protect investors from fraudulent activities. This was a crucial step in restoring confidence in the financial system after the stock market crash of 1929.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: FCC consolidated all federal regulation of telephone, telegraph, and radio communications
3.description: The FCC's consolidation of federal regulation of communication technologies aimed to streamline oversight and ensure fair and efficient communication services for the public. This was a significant development in the modernization of communication infrastructure in the United States.
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: Hottest temperatures on record and severe droughts
4.description: In 1934, the United States experienced record-breaking temperatures and severe droughts, leading to widespread agricultural and environmental challenges. These extreme weather conditions exacerbated the impact of the Great Depression on rural communities and agricultural production.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: Economic growth, unemployment rate, and debt increase
5.description: In 1934, the U.S. economy grew significantly in response to the New Deal programs, leading to a reduction in unemployment and a rise in prices. However, the national debt also increased to $27 billion, reflecting the complex economic dynamics during the Great Depression.
5.subject: Great Depression

6.name: Supreme Court declared the National Industrial Recovery Act unconstitutional
6.description: The Supreme Court's decision to declare the National Industrial Recovery Act unconstitutional had a profound impact on the New Deal policies and the government's role in regulating economic activities. This ruling reshaped the legal and political landscape during the Great Depression.
6.subject: Great Depression

7.name: Soil Conservation & Domestic Allotment Act paid farmers to plant soil-building crops
7.description: The Soil Conservation & Domestic Allotment Act aimed to address soil erosion and promote sustainable farming practices by providing financial incentives for farmers to plant soil-building crops. This initiative was crucial for revitalizing the agricultural sector during the Great Depression.
7.subject: Great Depression

8.name: Emergency Relief Appropriation created the Works Progress Administration
8.description: The Emergency Relief Appropriation led to the establishment of the Works Progress Administration, which employed millions of people in various public works projects, providing much-needed jobs and infrastructure improvements during the Great Depression.
8.subject: Great Depression

1.name: 연방 주택 관리청의 연방 모기지 보험 제공
1.description: 연방 주택 관리청은 주택 시장을 부흥시키고 미국인들에게 가격이 적은 주택을 제공하기 위해 연방 모기지 보험을 제공했다. 이는 대공황 기간 동안 경제를 촉진하고 주택 위기에 대처하기 위한 뉴딜 프로그램의 중요한 구성 요소였다.

2.name: 증권 거래위원회가 주식 시장을 규제했다
2.description: 증권 거래위원회는 주식 시장을 규제하고 투자자를 사기 행위로부터 보호하기 위해 설립되었다. 이는 1929년 주식 시장 붕괴 이후 금융 시스템에 대한 신뢰를 회복하는 중요한 단계였다.

3.name: FCC가 전화, 전보 및 무선 통신의 연방 규제를 통합했다
3.description: FCC의 통신 기술 연방 규제 통합은 감독을 간소화하고 대중을 위한 공정하고 효율적인 통신 서비스를 보장하기 위한 것이었다. 이는 미국 통신 인프라의 현대화에 있어서 중요한 발전이었다.

4.name: 토양 보전 및 농가 배정법이 토양 보전 작물을 심은 농부들에게 보상을 지불했다
4.description: 토양 보전 및 농가 배정법은 토양 침식에 대처하고 지속 가능한 농업 관행을 촉진하기 위해 토양 보전 작물을 심은 농부들에게 금전적 인센티브를 제공하는 것을 목표로 했다. 이러한 노력은 대공황 기간 동안 농업 부문을 재기하는 데 중요했다.

5.name: 비상 구호 배정금이 공공 사업 진행 행정부를 창설했다
5.description: 비상 구호 배정금은 공공 사업 진행 행정부의 설립으로 이어졌는데, 이는 대공황 기간 동안 많은 사람들을 고용시켜 다양한 공공 사업을 수행하여 필요한 일자리와 인프라 개선을 제공했다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1935 May 20: The Rural Electrification Act helped farms to generate electricity for their areas.22July: The National Labor Relations Act/Wagner Act protected workers' rights and created the National Labor Relations Board.

1935 April 30: The Resettlement Administration trained and provided loans to farmers.August: The Social Security Act provided income to the elderly, the blind, the disabled, and children in low-income families. It was paid for with payroll taxes and the Social Security Trust Fund.Economy grew 8.9%. Unemployment fell to 20.1%. Prices rose 3.0%. The debt rose to $29 billion.

1936:June: The hottest summer on record began.23 Eight states experienced temperatures of 110 degrees or greater.July: Twelve additional states experienced temperatures at or above 110 degrees, including four that broke 120 degrees.August: Texas experienced record-breaking temperatures of 120 degrees.24Throughout the year, the heat wave directly killed 1,693 people.25 Another 3,500 people drowned while trying to cool off.FDR raised the top tax rate to 79%. The economy grew 12.9%.Unemployment shrank to 16.9%. Prices rose 1.4%. The debt grew to $34 billion.

1.name: Rural Electrification Act
1.description: The Rural Electrification Act was passed on May 20, 1935, and it aimed to provide electricity to rural areas, particularly farms, which greatly improved their productivity and quality of life.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: National Labor Relations Act/Wagner Act
2.description: The National Labor Relations Act, also known as the Wagner Act, was enacted on July 22, 1935, to protect workers' rights and establish the National Labor Relations Board, ensuring fair labor practices and collective bargaining.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Resettlement Administration
3.description: The Resettlement Administration, established on April 30, 1935, provided training and loans to farmers, aiming to improve their living conditions and agricultural practices during the Great Depression.
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: Social Security Act
4.description: The Social Security Act, passed in August 1935, provided financial assistance to the elderly, disabled, and low-income families through payroll taxes, marking a significant social welfare reform during the Great Depression.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: Hottest Summer on Record
5.description: In June 1936, the United States experienced the hottest summer on record, with extreme temperatures causing significant human casualties and impacting various sectors of the economy.
5.subject: Great Depression

6.name: Continuation of Hottest Summer
6.description: In July 1936, the extreme heat wave continued, leading to further casualties and adverse effects on agriculture and public health, contributing to the challenges faced during the Great Depression.
6.subject: Great Depression

7.name: Record-breaking Temperatures in Texas
7.description: In August 1936, Texas experienced record-breaking temperatures of 120 degrees, exacerbating the impact of the hottest summer on record and adding to the challenges of the Great Depression.
7.subject: Great Depression

fine_tuning_training_set.input: [{'name': 'Rural Electrification Act', 'description': 'The Rural Electrification Act was passed on May 20, 1935, and it aimed to provide electricity to rural areas, particularly farms, which greatly improved their productivity and quality of life.', 'language_code_id': 2, 'event_id': 800}, {'name': 'National Labor Relations Act/Wagner Act', 'description': "The National Labor Relations Act, also known as the Wagner Act, was enacted on July 22, 1935, to protect workers' rights and establish the National Labor Relations Board, ensuring fair labor practices and collective bargaining.", 'language_code_id': 2, 'event_id': 801}, {'name': 'Resettlement Administration', 'description': 'The Resettlement Administration, established on April 30, 1935, provided training and loans to farmers, aiming to improve their living conditions and agricultural practices during the Great Depression.', 'language_code_id': 2, 'event_id': 802}]

1.name: 농촌 전기화법
1.description: 농촌 전기화법은 1935년 5월 20일에 통과되었으며, 주로 농장을 포함한 농촌 지역에 전기를 공급하여 생산성과 삶의 질을 크게 향상시키는 것을 목표로 했다.

2.name: 국가 노동 관계법/바그너법
2.description: 국가 노동 관계법인 바그너법으로도 알려진 국가 노동 관계법은 1935년 7월 22일에 제정되어 노동자의 권리를 보호하고 공정한 노동 관행과 단체교섭을 보장하기 위해 국가 노동 관계위원회를 설립했다.

3.name: 이주민 정착 행정청
3.description: 이주민 정착 행정청은 1935년 4월 30일에 설립되어 대공황 시기에 농부들의 생활 조건과 농업 관행을 개선하기 위해 훈련과 대출을 제공했다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input: 1937:the great depression billboardMarch 1937 A billboard, sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers, on Highway 99 in California during the Depression. It reads 'There's no way like the American way' and 'world's highest standard of living'. PHOTO BY DOROTHEA LANGE/LIBRARY OF CONGRESS/GETTY IMAGESFDR began his second term. He launched a third New Deal.The Wagner-Steagall Act funded state-run public housing projects. The Bonneville Power Administration delivered and sold power from the Bonneville Dam.The Farm Tenancy Act provided loans for tenant farmers to buy farms. The Farm Security Administration replaced the Resettlement Administration.FDR cut spending to reduce the debt. That cutback in New Deal spending pushed the economy back into the Depression.Roosevelt also pushed Congress to enact a $5 billion relief program. It included the Federal National Mortgage Association that resold mortgages on the secondary market.The New Agricultural Adjustment Act remedied the 1933 AAA. The Fair Labor Standards Act established the U.S. minimum wage, overtime pay, and youth employment standards.26May: The economy started contracting again, as the Depression resumed.27For the year, the economy grew 5.1%, unemployment fell to 14.3%, and prices rose 2.9%. The debt rose to $37 billion.

1.name: Great Depression Billboard in California
1.description: In March 1937, a billboard sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers was displayed on Highway 99 in California during the Great Depression. It featured the slogan 'There's no way like the American way' and 'world's highest standard of living'.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: FDR's Second Term and New Deal Initiatives
2.description: In 1937, Franklin D. Roosevelt began his second term as President and launched a third New Deal. This included initiatives such as the Wagner-Steagall Act funding state-run public housing projects, the Bonneville Power Administration delivering and selling power from the Bonneville Dam, and the Farm Tenancy Act providing loans for tenant farmers to buy farms.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Economic Impact of FDR's Policies
3.description: In 1937, FDR's decision to cut spending to reduce the debt had an unintended consequence, pushing the economy back into the Depression. This led to the enactment of a $5 billion relief program, including the Federal National Mortgage Association that resold mortgages on the secondary market.
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: New Agricultural Adjustment Act and Fair Labor Standards Act
4.description: In 1937, the New Agricultural Adjustment Act was introduced to remedy the 1933 AAA, and the Fair Labor Standards Act was established to set the U.S. minimum wage, overtime pay, and youth employment standards.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: Resumption of the Depression
5.description: On May 26, 1937, the economy started contracting again, marking the resumption of the Great Depression.
5.subject: Great Depression

fine_tuning_training_set.input: [{'name': 'Resumption of the Depression', 'description': 'On May 26, 1937, the economy started contracting again, marking the resumption of the Great Depression.', 'language_code_id': 2, 'event_id': 803}]

1.name: 우울증 재개
1.description: 1937년 5월 26일, 경제는 다시 수축하기 시작하여 대공황의 재개를 알렸다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1938:In 1938, FDR abolished mark to market accounting.28 Some experts believed it forced many banks out of business.The rule forced banks to write down their real estate as values fell. FDR's new rule allowed them to keep these assets on their books at historical prices.29June: The economy started to grow again. The Great Depression was over.For the year, the economy shrank 3.3%. Unemployment rose to 19%. Prices fell 2.8%.The debt remained steady at $37 billion.

1939:FDR Fireside ChatUNDERWOOD ARCHIVES / GETTY IMAGESThe drought returned. Louisiana experienced record temperatures.The Federal Security Agency was launched to administer Social Security, federal education funding, and food and drug safety.September: Hitler invaded Poland, starting World War II.November: FDR convinced Congress to repeal the U.S. military arms embargo to France and Britain.The economy grew 8%, unemployment fell to 17.2%, and prices remained flat. The debt rose to $40 billion.

1940:June: Hitler conquered France and bombed London. The United States began sending arms to Britain. Congress reinstated the military draft.FDR increased the defense budget and raised the top income tax rate to 81%.The economy grew 8.8%. Unemployment fell to 14.6%. Prices crept up 0.7%. The debt rose to $51 billion.

1.name: FDR abolishes mark to market accounting
1.description: In 1938, FDR abolished mark to market accounting, which some experts believed forced many banks out of business by allowing them to keep their assets on their books at historical prices. This had a significant impact on the banking industry during the Great Depression.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: Economy started to grow again
2.description: In June 1938, the economy started to grow again, marking the end of the Great Depression. Despite the growth, the economy still faced challenges such as high unemployment and falling prices.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Hitler invades Poland, starting World War II
3.description: In September 1939, Hitler invaded Poland, marking the beginning of World War II. This event had a profound impact on global politics and led to significant changes in the economic and social landscape.
3.subject: World War II

4.name: FDR convinces Congress to repeal U.S. military arms embargo
4.description: In November 1939, FDR convinced Congress to repeal the U.S. military arms embargo to France and Britain. This decision had a significant impact on the global military and political landscape during World War II.
4.subject: World War II

5.name: Hitler conquers France and bombs London
5.description: In June 1940, Hitler conquered France and bombed London, leading to significant changes in the course of World War II. This event marked a turning point in the war and had a profound impact on global politics and alliances.
5.subject: World War II

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1941:Shipbuilding during WW II.Shipbuilding during WW II. PHOTO: BY: FOX PHOTOS / GETTY IMAGESFDR began his third term.The drought ended as near-normal rainfall returned.March: The United States sent war supplies to England.October: Germany sank a U.S. Navy destroyer.

1941 Dec. 7: Japan attacked Pearl Harbor. Congress declared war on Japan.30The economy grew 17.7%, unemployment plummeted to 9.9%, and prices rose 9.9%. The debt grew to $58 billion.In total, FDR created the greatest percentage increase in U.S. debt by a president.

1954:

1954 Nov. 23: The Dow closed at 382.74. That was the first time it exceeded 381.7, the record set on Sept. 3, 1929.

1.name: Japan attacked Pearl Harbor
1.description: On December 7, 1941, Japan launched a surprise military strike on the United States naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, leading to the United States' entry into World War II.
1.subject: World War II

2.name: United States sent war supplies to England
2.description: In March 1941, the United States provided vital war supplies to England, playing a crucial role in supporting the Allied forces during World War II.
2.subject: World War II

3.name: Germany sank a U.S. Navy destroyer
3.description: In October 1941, Germany sank a U.S. Navy destroyer, escalating tensions between the United States and Germany before the country's entry into World War II.
3.subject: World War II

4.name: FDR began his third term
4.description: In 1941, Franklin D. Roosevelt began his third term as the President of the United States, marking a critical period in the country's leadership during World War II and the Great Depression.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: The drought ended as near-normal rainfall returned
5.description: In 1941, the drought in the United States ended as near-normal rainfall returned, providing relief to agricultural areas and contributing to the recovery from the Great Depression.
5.subject: Great Depression

6.name: The Dow closed at 382.74
6.description: On November 23, 1954, the Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 382.74, surpassing the previous record set on September 3, 1929, reflecting the post-World War II economic growth and recovery.
6.subject: Post-World War II Economy

1.name: 일본이 펄하버를 공격한 사건
1.description: 1941년 12월 7일, 일본은 하와이의 펄하버 해군기지에 서프라이즈 군사 공격을 발동하여 미국이 제2차 세계대전에 참전하게 되었다.

2.name: 다우가 382.74로 폐장한 사건
2.description: 1954년 11월 23일, 다우존스 산업평균지수는 382.74로 폐장하여 1929년 9월 3일에 세운 이전 기록을 뛰어넘었으며, 제2차 세계대전 이후의 경제 성장과 회복을 반영하고 있다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1930:U.S. population: 123,203,000

1930 June 17: The Smoot-Hawley Tariff raises duties on agricultural and manufactured goods, triggering foreign retaliation.

1931:

1931 March 3: President Herbert Hoover signs an act making the "Star-Spangled Banner" the national anthem.

1931 March 25: Nine black youths, the "Scottboro Boys, are charged with rape. The case established the right of African Americans to serve on juries.September: A bank panic leads 305 banks to close in September and another 522 in October.

1932:

1932 Jan 22: The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is established to provide loans to banks, railroads, and insurance companies.

1932 March 1: The son of aviator Charles Lindbergh is kidnapped.

1932 July 2: Democratic presidential candidate Franklin Roosevelt promises a "New Deal" for the American people.

1.name: The Smoot-Hawley Tariff
1.description: The Smoot-Hawley Tariff raised duties on agricultural and manufactured goods, leading to foreign retaliation and exacerbating the Great Depression.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: National Anthem Act
2.description: President Herbert Hoover signs an act making the 'Star-Spangled Banner' the national anthem of the United States.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Scottsboro Boys Case
3.description: Nine black youths, known as the 'Scottsboro Boys', are charged with rape, leading to a landmark case that established the right of African Americans to serve on juries.
3.subject: Civil Rights

4.name: Reconstruction Finance Corporation Establishment
4.description: The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is established to provide loans to banks, railroads, and insurance companies, aiming to stabilize the economy during the Great Depression.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: Lindbergh Kidnapping
5.description: The son of aviator Charles Lindbergh is kidnapped, leading to a high-profile and tragic criminal case.
5.subject: Crime and Justice

6.name: Franklin Roosevelt's 'New Deal' Promise
6.description: Democratic presidential candidate Franklin Roosevelt promises a 'New Deal' for the American people, marking a pivotal moment in U.S. history and the Great Depression era.
6.subject: Great Depression

1.name: 스무트-할리 관세법
1.description: 농업 및 제조업품에 관세를 인상시켜 외국의 보복을 일으키고 대공황을 악화시킨 스무트-할리 관세법.

2.name: 국가 국가 국가 국가
2.description: 허버트 후버 대통령이 '별들의 피아노'를 미국의 국가 애창곡으로 지정하는 법률에 서명함.

3.name: 스콧스보로 소년들 사건
3.description: '스콧스보로 소년들'이라 불리는 아프리카계 미국인 9명이 강간 혐의로 기소되어 아프리카계 미국인이 배심원으로 참여할 권리를 확립한 사례로 이어지는 사건.

4.name: 재건 금융 공사 설립
4.description: 대공황 기간 동안 경제를 안정화하기 위해 은행, 철도 및 보험회사에 대출을 제공하기 위해 재건 금융 공사가 설립됨.

5.name: 린드버그 유괴 사건
5.description: 비행사 찰스 린드버그의 아들이 유괴되어 고위험하고 비극적인 형사 사건으로 이어짐.

6.name: 프랭클린 루즈벨트의 '뉴딜' 약속
6.description: 민주당 대통령 후보 프랭클린 루즈벨트가 미국 역사와 대공황 시대의 중요한 순간을 표시하는 '뉴딜'을 미국인들에게 약속함.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1932 July 28: Bonus Army. President Herbert Hoover orders the army to remove 15,000 WWI veterans who had been camped in Washington for two months demanding early payment of a bonus due in 1945.

1933:

1933 January 30: Adolf Hitler, leader of Germany's Nazi party, is appointed Chancellor.

1933 March 4: Franklin D. Roosevelt becomes President and launches the New Deal. In his inaugural address, he says: "The only thing we have to fear is fear itself." During his first hundred days in office, Congress enacts the AAA, which provides farmers with payments for restricting production; establishes the Civil Works Administration and the Public Works Administration; and creates the Civilian Conservation Corps, the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal Communications Commission, and the Federal Bank Deposit Insurance Corporation.

1933 December 5: Prohibition is repealed.

1934:

1.name: Bonus Army removed from Washington
1.description: President Herbert Hoover orders the army to remove 15,000 WWI veterans who had been camped in Washington for two months demanding early payment of a bonus due in 1945. The veterans were forcibly evicted from their camp, leading to a violent clash with the authorities.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: Adolf Hitler appointed Chancellor of Germany
2.description: Adolf Hitler, leader of Germany's Nazi party, is appointed Chancellor, marking a significant turning point in German politics and paving the way for the establishment of a totalitarian regime.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt becomes President and launches the New Deal
3.description: Franklin D. Roosevelt becomes President and launches the New Deal, a series of programs and reforms aimed at addressing the economic challenges of the Great Depression. In his inaugural address, he delivers the iconic line: 'The only thing we have to fear is fear itself.'
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: Repeal of Prohibition
4.description: Prohibition, which banned the production, importation, and sale of alcoholic beverages, is repealed, ending a 13-year period of prohibition in the United States. This event marked a significant shift in social and legal policies.
4.subject: Great Depression

1.name: 보너스 군대의 워싱턴 철수
1.description: 허버트 후버 대통령이 1945년에 예정된 보너스를 조기 지급을 요구하며 워싱턴에 2개월 동안 캠핑한 1만 5천 명의 제1차 세계대전 참전 군인들을 제거하기 위해 군대에 명령을 내린 사건. 참전 군인들은 강제로 캠프에서 내쫓기며 당국과의 격렬한 충돌을 일으켰다.

2.name: 아돌프 히틀러의 독일 총리 임명
2.description: 독일 나치당 지도자인 아돌프 히틀러가 총리로 임명되어 독일 정치의 중요한 전환점을 마킹하고 전체주의 체제의 수립을 이끌어내는 사건.

3.name: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트 대통령 취임 및 뉴딜 캠페인 시작
3.description: 프랭클린 D. 루즈벨트가 대통령으로 취임하고 대공황의 경제적 도전에 대처하기 위한 일련의 프로그램과 개혁을 시작하는 뉴딜 캠페인을 시작한 사건. 취임 연설에서 그는 '우리가 두려워해야 할 유일한 것은 두려움 그 자체뿐이다.'라는 상징적인 문구를 전달했다.

4.name: 금지법 폐지
4.description: 주류의 생산, 수입 및 판매를 금지했던 금지법이 폐지되어 미국의 13년간의 금지 시대를 종식시키는 사건. 이 사건은 사회적, 법적 정책에서의 중요한 변화를 나타내는 사건이었다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1934 January 1: Dr. Francis Townsend, a 66-year-old retired dentist, proposes federally-funded pensions for the elderly.

1934 July 22: Public Enemy Number 1, bank robber John Dillinger, is shot and killed by the FBI while leaving a movie theater in Chicago.

1934 September 15: The Nuremberg Laws strip German Jews of and prohibit intermarriage with non-Jews.

1935:

1935 May 27: The Supreme Court declares the national industrial Recovery Act unconstitutional, suggesting that any federal effort to legislate wages, prices, and working conditions was invalid.

1935 June 10: Alcoholic Anonymous is organized in New York City.

1935 July 5: The Wagner Act guarantees workers' right to bargain collectively.

1935 August 14: President Roosevelt signs the Social Security Act.

1935 September 8: Huey Long is assassinated in Louisiana's state capitol.

1.name: Dr. Francis Townsend proposes federally-funded pensions for the elderly
1.description: Dr. Francis Townsend, a retired dentist, advocates for the establishment of federally-funded pensions to support the elderly population, aiming to address the economic challenges faced by senior citizens during the Great Depression.
1.subject: Great Depression

2.name: John Dillinger is shot and killed by the FBI
2.description: John Dillinger, notorious bank robber and Public Enemy Number 1, is fatally shot by the FBI as he exits a movie theater in Chicago, marking a significant event in the pursuit of justice against organized crime during the Great Depression era.
2.subject: Great Depression

3.name: The Nuremberg Laws strip German Jews of citizenship and prohibit intermarriage with non-Jews
3.description: The Nuremberg Laws, enacted by the Nazi regime, deprive German Jews of their citizenship and impose severe restrictions on their rights, leading to widespread discrimination and persecution within the society.
3.subject: Great Depression

4.name: The Supreme Court declares the national industrial Recovery Act unconstitutional
4.description: The Supreme Court's ruling declares the national industrial Recovery Act unconstitutional, signaling a shift in the balance of power between federal legislation and economic regulations, impacting the government's intervention in labor and business practices during the Great Depression.
4.subject: Great Depression

5.name: Alcoholic Anonymous is organized in New York City
5.description: Alcoholic Anonymous, a support group for individuals struggling with alcohol addiction, is founded in New York City, providing a platform for mutual aid and sobriety maintenance during a time of social and economic turmoil.
5.subject: Great Depression

6.name: The Wagner Act guarantees workers' right to bargain collectively
6.description: The Wagner Act, also known as the National Labor Relations Act, secures the rights of workers to engage in collective bargaining and protects their freedom to organize labor unions, marking a pivotal development in labor rights and industrial relations during the Great Depression.
6.subject: Great Depression

7.name: President Roosevelt signs the Social Security Act
7.description: President Roosevelt signs the Social Security Act into law, establishing a system of social insurance to provide economic security for the elderly, unemployed, and disadvantaged individuals, representing a landmark initiative in the development of social welfare programs during the Great Depression.
7.subject: Great Depression

8.name: Huey Long is assassinated in Louisiana's state capitol
8.description: Huey Long, a prominent political figure and advocate for wealth redistribution, is assassinated in Louisiana's state capitol, marking the tragic end of his influential populist movement during the Great Depression era.
8.subject: Great Depression

1.name: Dr. Francis Townsend의 연방 기금 연금 제안
1.description: 퇴직한 치과의사인 Dr. Francis Townsend는 노인들을 지원하기 위해 연방 기금 연금을 설립하고자 하며, 대공황 시기의 노인들이 직면한 경제적 어려움에 대처하고자 합니다.

2.name: John Dillinger가 FBI에 의해 총에 맞고 사망
2.description: 악명 높은 은행 강도이자 공공의 적 1호인 John Dillinger가 시카고의 영화관을 나오는 도중 FBI에 의해 치명적으로 총에 맞아 사망하며, 대공황 시대 조직 범죄에 대한 정의 추구에서 중요한 사건으로 기록됩니다.

3.name: Nuremberg Laws가 독일 유대인에게 시민권을 박탈하고 비유대인과의 혼인을 금지
3.description: 나치 정권에 의해 제정된 Nuremberg Laws는 독일 유대인들의 시민권을 박탈하고 그들의 권리에 심각한 제약을 가하며, 사회 내에서의 널리 퍼진 차별과 박해로 이어집니다.

4.name: Supreme Court가 국가 산업 회복법을 헌법 불합치로 선언
4.description: 대법원의 판결은 국가 산업 회복법을 헌법 불합치로 선언하여 연방 입법과 경제 규제 사이의 권력 균형에서 변화를 시사하며, 대공황 시기의 노동 및 사업 관행에 대한 정부 개입에 영향을 미칩니다.

5.name: Alcoholic Anonymous가 뉴욕시에서 조직됨
5.description: 알코올 중독으로 고통받는 개인들을 위한 지원 그룹인 Alcoholic Anonymous가 뉴욕시에서 설립되어 사회적 경제적 격동기에 상호 지원과 금주 유지를 위한 플랫폼을 제공합니다.

6.name: Wagner Act가 노동자들의 단체 교섭권을 보장
6.description: Wagner Act 또는 국가 노동 관계법으로 알려진 이 법은 노동자들의 단체 교섭에 참여할 권리를 보장하고 노동 조합을 조직하는 자유를 보호하여 대공황 시대의 노동 권리와 산업 관계의 중요한 발전을 나타냅니다.

7.name: Roosevelt 대통령이 사회보장법에 서명
7.description: Roosevelt 대통령이 사회보장법에 서명하여 노인, 실직자 및 불우한 개인들을 위한 경제적 안전망을 확립하며, 대공황 시대 사회 복지 프로그램 발전의 중요한 계기로 인식됩니다.

8.name: Huey Long이 루이지애나 주 의회에서 암살당함
8.description: 부와 재분배를 옹호하는 중요한 정치적 인물인 Huey Long이 루이지애나 주 의회에서 암살당하여 그의 영향력 있는 인민주의 운동의 비극적인 끝을 맞이하게 됩니다.

fine_tuning_training_set.input:
1935 October 18: The Committee for Industrial Organization is formed with John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, as its head. In 1938, it became the Congress of Industrial Organizations. Unlike the AFL, it did not limit membership to skilled workers.

1936:

1936 March 7: In violation of the Versailles Treaty ending WWI, 4,000 German troops occupy the Rhineland.Summer: Jesse Owens wins four medals at the Olympics in Berlin, rebutting Hitler's claims about the superiority of the Aryan race.

1936 July 17: Civil War erupts in Spain, ending the country's five year experiment with democracy. Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini provide arms to Gen. Francisco Franco, who defeats the Loyalists in 1939 and imposes a dictatorship.

1.name: Formation of the Committee for Industrial Organization
1.description: The Committee for Industrial Organization was formed with John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, as its head. It later became the Congress of Industrial Organizations in 1938, and unlike the AFL, it did not limit membership to skilled workers.
1.subject: Labor Movement

2.name: German Troops Occupy the Rhineland
2.description: In violation of the Versailles Treaty ending WWI, 4,000 German troops occupy the Rhineland, escalating tensions in Europe.
2.subject: World War II

3.name: Civil War Erupts in Spain
3.description: Civil War erupts in Spain, ending the country's five-year experiment with democracy. Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini provide arms to Gen. Francisco Franco, who defeats the Loyalists in 1939 and imposes a dictatorship.
3.subject: Spanish Civil War
